Diagnose, treat, and help prevent diseases and injuries in children. May refer patients to specialists for further diagnosis or treatment, as needed. Excludes Family Medicine Physicians (29-1215) and General Internal Medicine Physicians (29-1216).
Diagnose diseases and conduct lab tests using organs, body tissues, and fluids. Includes medical examiners.
Diagnose, treat, and help prevent mental disorders. Excludes Clinical and Counseling Psychologists (19-3033) and School Psychologists (19-3034).

Diagnose and treat diseases and injuries using medical imaging techniques, such as x rays, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), nuclear medicine, and ultrasounds. May perform minimally invasive medical procedures and tests.
All physicians not listed separately.

SOC 29-1240 refers to surgeons who diagnose and perform surgery on various conditions affecting the eyes (excluding pediatric cases), musculoskeletal system (excluding pediatric cases), and other general surgical procedures not covered in specific subcategories, excluding pediatric or maxillofacial cases.

Diagnose and perform surgery to treat and help prevent disorders and diseases of the eye. May also provide vision services for treatment including glasses and contacts. Excludes Optometrists (29-1041) and Pediatric Surgeons (29-1243).
Diagnose and perform surgery to treat and prevent rheumatic and other diseases in the musculoskeletal system. Excludes Pediatric Surgeons (29-1243).

Diagnose and perform surgery to treat fetal abnormalities and birth defects, diseases, and injuries in fetuses, premature and newborn infants, children, and adolescents. Includes all pediatric surgical specialties and subspecialties. Excludes Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons (29-1022), Ophthalmologists, Except Pediatric (29-1241), and Orthopedic Surgeons, Except Pediatric (29-1242).
All surgeons not listed separately. Excludes Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons (29-1022).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Healthcare Diagnosing or Treating Practitioners
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 29-1290, "Miscellaneous Healthcare Diagnosing or Treating Practitioners," encompasses healthcare professionals such as acupuncturists who diagnose and treat disorders through alternative therapies like acupuncture, dental hygienists who provide oral care services, and other miscellaneous practitioners involved in the diagnosis and treatment of various conditions not specified elsewhere.

Diagnose, treat, and prevent disorders by stimulating specific acupuncture points within the body using acupuncture needles. May also use cups, nutritional supplements, therapeutic massage, acupressure, and other alternative health therapies. Excludes Chiropractors (29-1011).

Administer oral hygiene care to patients. Assess patient oral hygiene problems or needs and maintain health records. Advise patients on oral health maintenance and disease prevention. May provide advanced care such as providing fluoride treatment or administering topical anesthesia.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Healthcare Diagnosing or Treating Practitioners, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All healthcare diagnosing or treating practitioners not listed separately.

This occupational category encompasses various healthcare professionals who perform specialized tasks in medical fields such as orthopedics, prosthetics, and hearing aid fitting, not explicitly covered by other categories.

The "Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians" occupational category includes professionals who perform complex or routine medical laboratory tests for diagnosing, treating, and preventing diseases, with technologists often overseeing and training technicians.
Perform complex medical laboratory tests for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. May train or supervise staff.
Perform routine medical laboratory tests for the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. May work under the supervision of a medical technologist.

The SOC group "Diagnosti Related Technologist and Technicians" encompasses professionals who perform various diagnostic tests using techniques such as nuclear medicine, cardiac catheterization, sonography, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and radiology to assist in the diagnosis, treatment, and research of medical conditions.

Conduct tests on pulmonary or cardiovascular systems of patients for diagnostic, therapeutic, or research purposes. May conduct or assist in electrocardiograms, cardiac catheterizations, pulmonary functions, lung capacity, and similar tests.
Produce ultrasonic recordings of internal organs for use by physicians. Includes vascular technologists. Excludes Cardiovascular Technologists and Technicians (29-2031).

Prepare, administer, and measure radioactive isotopes in therapeutic, diagnostic, and tracer studies using a variety of radioisotope equipment. Prepare stock solutions of radioactive materials and calculate doses to be administered by radiologists. Subject patients to radiation. Execute blood volume, red cell survival, and fat absorption studies following standard laboratory techniques.

Take x-rays and CAT scans or administer nonradioactive materials into patient’s bloodstream for diagnostic or research purposes. Includes radiologic technologists and technicians who specialize in other scanning modalities. Excludes Diagnostic Medical Sonographers (29-2032) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging Technologists (29-2035).

Operate Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scanners. Monitor patient safety and comfort, and view images of area being scanned to ensure quality of pictures. May administer gadolinium contrast dosage intravenously. May interview patient, explain MRI procedures, and position patient on examining table. May enter into the computer data such as patient history, anatomical area to be scanned, orientation specified, and position of entry.
Generate radiation treatment plans, develop radiation dose calculations, communicate and supervise the treatment plan implementation, and consult with members of radiation oncology team.

The SOC Group 29-2040 refers to professionals who provide emergency medical care and transportation for injured or ill individuals, with Emergency Medical Technicians offering basic life support and Paramedic providing advanced life support services.

Assess injuries and illnesses and administer basic emergency medical care. May transport injured or sick persons to medical facilities. Excludes Paramedics (29-2043), Firefighters (33-2011), and Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians (53-3011).

Administer basic or advanced emergency medical care and assess injuries and illnesses. May administer medication intravenously, use equipment such as EKGs, or administer advanced life support to sick or injured individuals. Excludes Emergency Medical Technicians (29-2042) and Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians (53-3011).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Health Practitioner Support Technologists and Technicians
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 29-2050, Health Practitioner Support Technologist and Technicians, encompasses professionals who assist healthcare practitioners in various fields such as dietary, pharmaceutical, mental health, surgical, veterinary, ophthalmic, and other specialized areas by providing technical support and services.

Assist in the provision of food service and nutritional programs, under the supervision of a dietitian. May plan and produce meals based on established guidelines, teach principles of food and nutrition, or counsel individuals.
Prepare medications under the direction of a pharmacist. May measure, mix, count out, label, and record amounts and dosages of medications according to prescription orders.

Care for individuals with mental or emotional conditions or disabilities, following the instructions of physicians or other health practitioners. Monitor patients’ physical and emotional well-being and report to medical staff. May participate in rehabilitation and treatment programs, help with personal hygiene, and administer oral or injectable medications.

Assist in operations, under the supervision of surgeons, registered nurses, or other surgical personnel. May help set up operating room, prepare and transport patients for surgery, adjust lights and equipment, pass instruments and other supplies to surgeons and surgeons’ assistants, hold retractors, cut sutures, and help count sponges, needles, supplies, and instruments. Excludes Surgical Assistants (29-9093).

Perform medical tests in a laboratory environment for use in the treatment and diagnosis of diseases in animals. Prepare vaccines and serums for prevention of diseases. Prepare tissue samples, take blood samples, and execute laboratory tests, such as urinalysis and blood counts. Clean and sterilize instruments and materials and maintain equipment and machines. May assist a veterinarian during surgery.
Assist ophthalmologists by performing ophthalmic clinical functions. May administer eye exams, administer eye medications, and instruct the patient in care and use of corrective lenses.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: License Practical and Vocational Nurses are healthcare professionals who provide patient care in various settings under the supervision of registered nurses or physicians.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Care for ill, injured, or convalescing patients or persons with disabilities in hospitals, nursing homes, clinics, private homes, group homes, and similar institutions. May work under the supervision of a registered nurse. Licensing required.

A medical records specialist is a professional responsible for compiling, processing, and maintaining patient medical records in accordance with healthcare industry standards, including coding diagnoses, procedures, and services using numerical systems.

Compile, process, and maintain medical records of hospital and clinic patients in a manner consistent with medical, administrative, ethical, legal, and regulatory requirements of the healthcare system. Classify medical and healthcare concepts, including diagnosis, procedures, medical services, and equipment, into the healthcare industry’s numerical coding system. Includes medical coders. Excludes Health Information Technologists and Medical Registrars (29-9021) and File Clerks (43-4071).

An optician in dispensing is a professional who specializes in designing, measuring, and fitting eyeglasses or contact lenses for clients based on written optical prescriptions, assisting with frame selection, and ensuring proper fit and adjustment of eyewear.

Design, measure, fit, and adapt lenses and frames for client according to written optical prescription or specification. Assist client with inserting, removing, and caring for contact lenses. Assist client with selecting frames. Measure customer for size of eyeglasses and coordinate frames with facial and eye measurements and optical prescription. Prepare work order for optical laboratory containing instructions for grinding and mounting lenses in frames. Verify exactness of finished lens spectacles. Adjust frame and lens position to fit client. May shape or reshape frames. Includes contact lens opticians.

The SOC group 29-2090, Miscellaneous Health Technologists and Technicians, encompasses professionals in healthcare who specialize in various medical fields not explicitly categorized elsewhere, such as orthopedic technicians designing braces or prosthetics, hearing aid specialists fitting devices for customers, and other health technologists and technicians with diverse roles.
Design, measure, fit, and adapt orthopedic braces, appliances or prostheses, such as limbs or facial parts for patients with disabling conditions.

Select and fit hearing aids for customers. Administer and interpret tests of hearing. Assess hearing instrument efficacy. Take ear impressions and prepare, design, and modify ear molds. Excludes Audiologists (29-1181).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Health Technologists and Technicians, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All health technologists and technicians not listed separately.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Other Healthcare Practitioners and Technical Occupations
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A broad occupational group encompassing various roles in the healthcare sector, including but not limited to Health Information Technologists and Medical Registrars who manage patient data systems, Athletic Trainers specializing in musculoskeletal injuries, Genealogical Counselors providing genetic risk assessments and advice, and other miscellaneous practitioners involved in healthcare services.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Health Information Technologists and Medical Registrars
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Health Information Technologist or Medical Registrar is a professional who utilizes their understanding of healthcare and information systems to design, develop, and analyze computerized patient data systems, excluding tasks performed by Medical Records Specialists.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Health Information Technologists and Medical Registrars
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Apply knowledge of healthcare and information systems to assist in the design, development, and continued modification and analysis of computerized healthcare systems. Abstract, collect, and analyze treatment and followup information of patients. May educate staff and assist in problem solving to promote the implementation of the healthcare information system. May design, develop, test, and implement databases with complete history, diagnosis, treatment, and health status to help monitor diseases. Excludes Medical Records Specialists (29‐2072).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Health Practitioners and Technical Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 29-9090 encompasses healthcare professionals who provide specialized services such as athletic trainers treating musculoskeletal injuries, genetic counselors assessing and advising on inherited conditions, surgical assistants supporting surgeons during operations, and other unspecified health practitioners.
Evaluate and treat musculoskeletal injuries or illnesses. Provide preventive, therapeutic, emergency, and rehabilitative care. Excludes Physical Therapists (29-1123).

Assess individual or family risk for a variety of inherited conditions, such as genetic disorders and birth defects. Provide information to other healthcare providers or to individuals and families concerned with the risk of inherited conditions. Advise individuals and families to support informed decisionmaking and coping methods for those at risk. May help conduct research related to genetic conditions or genetic counseling.

Assist in operations, under the supervision of surgeons. May, in accordance with state laws, help surgeons to make incisions and close surgical sites, manipulate or remove tissues, implant surgical devices or drains, suction the surgical site, place catheters, clamp or cauterize vessels or tissue, and apply dressings to surgical site. Excludes Registered Nurses (29-1141) and Surgical Technologists (29-2055).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Healthcare Practitioners and Technical Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All healthcare practitioners and technical workers not listed separately.

Healthcare support occupations encompass various roles in the healthcare industry that assist licensed professionals in performing tasks such as preparing patients and equipment, administering medication under supervision, and maintaining medical records.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Home Health and Personal Care Aides; and Nursing Assistants, Orderlies, and Psychiatric Aides
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Home Health and Personal Care Aides; Nurse Assistants, Orderlies, and Psychiatric Aides are healthcare professionals who provide direct care and support to individuals with disabilities or illnesses in various settings, assisting with personal care tasks, activities of daily living, routine healthcare needs, and maintaining a safe environment under the supervision of licensed nursing staff.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Home Health and Personal Care Aides
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC Code 31-1120 Home Health and Personal Care Aides are healthcare professionals who provide direct care to individuals with disabilities or illnesses, assisting with personal care tasks, activities of daily living, and routine healthcare needs in various settings.

Monitor the health status of an individual with disabilities or illness, and address their health-related needs, such as changing bandages, dressing wounds, or administering medication. Work is performed under the direction of offsite or intermittent onsite licensed nursing staff. Provide assistance with routine healthcare tasks or activities of daily living, such as feeding, bathing, toileting, or ambulation. May also help with tasks such as preparing meals, doing light housekeeping, and doing laundry depending on the patient’s abilities.

Provide personalized assistance to individuals with disabilities or illness who require help with personal care and activities of daily living support (e.g., feeding, bathing, dressing, grooming, toileting, and ambulation). May also provide help with tasks such as preparing meals, doing light housekeeping, and doing laundry. Work is performed in various settings depending on the needs of the care recipient and may include locations such as their home, place of work, out in the community, or at a daytime nonresidential facility.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Nursing Assistants, Orderlies, and Psychiatric Aides
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A role in healthcare settings that involves providing basic care and support to patients under the supervision of licensed nursing staff, including tasks such as monitoring health status, assisting with daily activities, transportation, and maintaining a safe environment.

Provide or assist with basic care or support under the direction of onsite licensed nursing staff. Perform duties such as monitoring of health status, feeding, bathing, dressing, grooming, toileting, or ambulation of patients in a health or nursing facility. May include medication administration and other health-related tasks. Includes nursing care attendants, nursing aides, and nursing attendants. Excludes Home Health Aides (31-1121), Personal Care Aides (31-1122), Orderlies (31-1132), and Psychiatric Aides (31-1133).

Transport patients to areas such as operating rooms or x-ray rooms using wheelchairs, stretchers, or moveable beds. May maintain stocks of supplies or clean and transport equipment. Excludes Nursing Assistants (31-1131). Psychiatric orderlies are included in Psychiatric Aides (31-1133).

Assist mentally impaired or emotionally disturbed patients, working under direction of nursing and medical staff. May assist with daily living activities, lead patients in educational and recreational activities, or accompany patients to and from examinations and treatments. May restrain violent patients. Includes psychiatric orderlies.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Occupational Therapy and Physical Therapist Assistants and Aides
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 31-2000 encompasses healthcare professionals who assist in providing physical therapy and occupational therapy services to patients under close supervision, with a focus on supporting therapists in treatment planning, implementation, and documentation.

Occupational Therapy Assistants and Aides are healthcare professionals who support occupational therapists in providing therapeutic treatments to patients, with assistants having formal training and aiding in treatment planning, while aides perform routine tasks under close supervision.

Assist occupational therapists in providing occupational therapy treatments and procedures. May, in accordance with state laws, assist in development of treatment plans, carry out routine functions, direct activity programs, and document the progress of treatments. Generally requires formal training.

Under close supervision of an occupational therapist or occupational therapy assistant, perform only delegated, selected, or routine tasks in specific situations. These duties include preparing patient and treatment room.

A Physical Therapist Assistant or Aide is a healthcare professional who supports physical therapists in providing care to patients with injuries or illnesses affecting their movement and functional ability.

Assist physical therapists in providing physical therapy treatments and procedures. May, in accordance with state laws, assist in the development of treatment plans, carry out routine functions, document the progress of treatment, and modify specific treatments in accordance with patient status and within the scope of treatment plans established by a physical therapist. Generally requires formal training.

Under close supervision of a physical therapist or physical therapy assistant, perform only delegated, selected, or routine tasks in specific situations. These duties include preparing the patient and the treatment area.

The SOC group 31-9090, Minor Healthcare Support Occupations, encompasses various healthcare roles such as massage therapists, dental and medical assistants, pharmaceutical aides, transcriptionists, equipment preparers, veterinary assistants, phlebotoists, and other miscellaneous support workers who perform administrative tasks, limited clinical duties, or specialized functions under the supervision of licensed professionals.
SOC 31-9010 Massage Therapists are healthcare professionals who specialize in performing therapeutic massages on soft tissues and joints, often assisting in assessments and therapy plan proposals.
Perform therapeutic massages of soft tissues and joints. May assist in the assessment of range of motion and muscle strength, or propose client therapy plans.

The SOC group 31-9090, Miscellaneous Healthcare Support Occupations, encompasses various healthcare roles such as dental assistants, medical and veterinary assistants, pharmacy aides, transcriptionists, and other support workers who perform administrative tasks, limited clinical duties, or specialized functions like drawing blood under the supervision of licensed professionals.

Perform limited clinical duties under the direction of a dentist. Clinical duties may include equipment preparation and sterilization, preparing patients for treatment, assisting the dentist during treatment, and providing patients with instructions for oral healthcare procedures. May perform administrative duties such as scheduling appointments, maintaining medical records, billing, and coding information for insurance purposes.

Perform administrative and certain clinical duties under the direction of a physician. Administrative duties may include scheduling appointments, maintaining medical records, billing, and coding information for insurance purposes. Clinical duties may include taking and recording vital signs and medical histories, preparing patients for examination, drawing blood, and administering medications as directed by physician. Excludes Physician Assistants (29-1071).
Prepare, sterilize, install, or clean laboratory or healthcare equipment. May perform routine laboratory tasks and operate or inspect equipment.

Transcribe medical reports recorded by physicians and other healthcare practitioners using various electronic devices, covering office visits, emergency room visits, diagnostic imaging studies, operations, chart reviews, and final summaries. Transcribe dictated reports and translate abbreviations into fully understandable form. Edit as necessary and return reports in either printed or electronic form for review and signature, or correction.
Record drugs delivered to the pharmacy, store incoming merchandise, and inform the supervisor of stock needs. May operate cash register and accept prescriptions for filling.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Feed, water, and examine pets and other nonfarm animals for signs of illness, disease, or injury in laboratories and animal hospitals and clinics. Clean and disinfect cages and work areas, and sterilize laboratory and surgical equipment. May provide routine postoperative care, administer medication orally or topically, or prepare samples for laboratory examination under the supervision of veterinary or laboratory animal technologists or technicians, veterinarians, or scientists. Excludes Animal Caretakers (39-2021).
Draw blood for tests, transfusions, donations, or research. May explain the procedure to patients and assist in the recovery of patients with adverse reactions.
All healthcare support workers not listed separately.

This occupational category refers to professionals who enforce laws and maintain order in various settings, including police officers at different levels of government or educational institutions, transit and railroad patrol officers, animal control workers, private detectives, gamble surveillance officers, security guards, crossing guards, life guarding and ski patrol personnel, school bus monitors, and other protective service workers.

A "Supervisor of Protective Service Workers" is a first-line supervisory role responsible for overseeing and coordinating the activities of various protective service workers, including but not limited to security personnel, law enforcement officers, correctional officers, firefighters, and other protective service workers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Law Enforcement Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 33-1010 First-Line Supervisor of Law Enforcement Workers encompasses roles responsible for overseeing and coordinating the activities of correctional officers and police force members at an initial supervisory level.
Directly supervise and coordinate activities of correctional officers and jailers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Police and Detectives
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of members of police force.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Firefighting and Prevention Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A First-Line Supervisor of Firefighting and Prevention Workers is responsible for overseeing and coordinating the activities of workers involved in firefighting and fire prevention efforts.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Firefighting and Prevention Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of workers engaged in firefighting and fire prevention and control.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous First-Line Supervisors, Protective Service Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 33-1090, Broad First-Line Supervisors of Protective Service Workers, encompasses supervisors who oversee and manage security personnel, including guards and other protective service workers not listed in other subcategories.
Directly supervise and coordinate activities of security workers and security guards.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Protective Service Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All protective service supervisors not listed separately above.

The SOC Group 33-2010 Firefighting and Prevention Workers encompasses professionals who protect lives, property, and the environment by controlling fires, providing emergency medical services, enforcing safety regulations, investigating hazards, and implementing prevention measures.
SOC Group 33-2010 Firefighters are emergency responders who control fires, provide emergency medical services, and manage various hazardous situations to protect life, property, and the environment.

Control and extinguish fires or respond to emergency situations where life, property, or the environment is at risk. Duties may include fire prevention, emergency medical service, hazardous material response, search and rescue, and disaster assistance.
Fire Inspectors are professionals responsible for inspecting buildings and forests to detect fire hazards, enforce safety regulations, and investigate fires to determine their causes.
Inspect buildings to detect fire hazards and enforce local ordinances and state laws, or investigate and gather facts to determine cause of fires and explosions.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Forest Fire Inspectors and Prevention Specialists
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Enforce fire regulations, inspect forest for fire hazards, and recommend forest fire prevention or control measures. May report forest fires and weather conditions.

A "Law Enforcement Worker" is an umbrella term for professionals who maintain order and enforce laws at various levels of government or educational institutions, including but not limited to police officers, park rangers, detectives, and fish and game wardens.
Bailliffs maintain order in courts of law, while Correctional Officers and Jailers guard inmates in penal or rehabilitative institutions, ensuring adherence to established regulations and procedures.
Maintain order in courts of law.

Guard inmates in penal or rehabilitative institutions in accordance with established regulations and procedures. May guard prisoners in transit between jail, courtroom, prison, or other point. Includes deputy sheriffs and police who spend the majority of their time guarding prisoners in correctional institutions.
Detectives and Criminal Investigators are professionals who investigate suspected violations of federal, state, or local laws to prevent and solve crimes, excluding private investigations.
Conduct investigations related to suspected violations of federal, state, or local laws to prevent or solve crimes. Excludes Private Detectives and Investigators (33-9021).
Fish and Game Wardens are law enforcement officers who primarily focus on preventing violations of fish and game laws, protecting wildlife resources, and maintaining ecological balance.
Patrol assigned area to prevent fish and game law violations. Investigate reports of damage to crops or property by wildlife. Compile biological data.

SOC Group 33-3040 refers to Parking Enforcement Workers who are responsible for patrolling designated areas, such as public parking lots and city streets, to issue tickets to vehicles that violate parking regulations.
Patrol assigned area, such as public parking lot or city streets to issue tickets to overtime parking violators and illegally parked vehicles.

A broad occupational category encompassing professionals who maintain order, protect life and property, enforce laws, direct traffic, investigate accidents, apprehend suspects, and serve legal processes at various levels of government or educational institutions.

Maintain order and protect life and property by enforcing local, tribal, state, or federal laws and ordinances. Perform a combination of the following duties: patrol a specific area; direct traffic; issue traffic summonses; investigate accidents; apprehend and arrest suspects, or serve legal processes of courts. Includes police officers working at educational institutions.
Protect and police railroad and transit property, employees, or passengers.

This SOC group encompasses various protective service roles focused on ensuring safety and security in diverse settings, including animal control, private investigation, gambling surveillance, security guarding, crossing guiding, recreational area protection, transportation screening, school bus monitoring, and other miscellaneous protective tasks.

SOC Group: Broad - 33-9010 Animal Control Workers are professionals who manage and care for animals in various situations, such as investigating animal mistreatment or controlling abandoned, dangerous, or unattended animals.
Handle animals for the purpose of investigations of mistreatment, or control of abandoned, dangerous, or unattended animals.

Private Detectives and Investigators are professionals who gather, analyze, and report information about individuals or organizations to clients, often focusing on detecting unlawful activities or rule infractions within private establishments.
Gather, analyze, compile, and report information regarding individuals or organizations to clients, or detect occurrences of unlawful acts or infractions of rules in private establishment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Security Guards and Gambling Surveillance Officers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Security Guard and Gambling Surveillance Officer is an occupation responsible for overseeing gaming operations to prevent irregular activities such as cheating or theft by patrons or employees, while also providing security services to protect premises from potential threats.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Gambling Surveillance Officers and Gambling Investigators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Observe gambling operation for irregular activities such as cheating or theft by either employees or patrons. Investigate potential threats to gambling assets such as money, chips, and gambling equipment. Act as oversight and security agent for management and customers.

Guard, patrol, or monitor premises to prevent theft, violence, or infractions of rules. May operate x-ray and metal detector equipment. Excludes Police Officers (33-3050) and Transportation Security Screeners (33-9093).

Miscellaneous Protective Service Workers are professionals who perform various safety and security roles in different settings, including guiding traffic at construction sites or recreational areas, screening passengers and cargo for compliance with regulations, maintaining order on school buses, and other protective service tasks not specifically categorized elsewhere.
Guide or control vehicular or pedestrian traffic at such places as streets, schools, railroad crossings, or construction sites.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Lifeguards, Ski Patrol, and Other Recreational Protective Service Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Monitor recreational areas, such as pools, beaches, or ski slopes, to provide assistance and protection to participants.

Conduct screening of passengers, baggage, or cargo to ensure compliance with Transportation Security Administration (TSA) regulations. May operate basic security equipment such as x-ray machines and hand wands at screening checkpoints.

Maintain order among students on a school bus. Duties include helping students safely board and exit and communicating behavioral problems. May perform pretrip and posttrip inspections and prepare for and assist in emergency evacuations.
All protective service workers not listed separately.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Food Preparation and Serving Related Occupations
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC group 35-9090 refers to individuals engaged in various roles within food preparation and serving settings, including cooking, bartending, fast food work, counter service, non-restaurant food service, and other related tasks not explicitly categorized under the broader classification.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Food Preparation and Serving Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Supervisorsof Food Preparaion and Servicing Workers (SOC 35-1010) are individuals responsible for overseeing and managing food preparation and serving tasks in various settings, including planning, organizing, directing, and sometimes participating in the preparation of meals.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Food Preparation and Serving Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC 35-1010 refers to individuals who oversee and manage the work of food preparation and serving workers, including planning, organizing, and directing tasks related to food preparation and service in various settings.

Direct and may participate in the preparation, seasoning, and cooking of salads, soups, fish, meats, vegetables, desserts, or other foods. May plan and price menu items, order supplies, and keep records and accounts.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Food Preparation and Serving Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of workers engaged in preparing and serving food.

SOC Group Minor SOC Code 35-2000 Cooks and Food Preparation Workers refers to culinary professionals who prepare and cook food in various settings such as fast food restaurants, institutional kitchens, private households, and cafeterias, excluding tasks limited to slipping meat or brewing beverages.

Cooks are culinary professionals who prepare and cook various types of food in different settings, including fast food restaurants, institutional kitchens, private households, and short order establishments.

Prepare and cook food in a fast food restaurant with a limited menu. Duties of these cooks are limited to preparation of a few basic items and normally involve operating large-volume single-purpose cooking equipment.
Prepare and cook large quantities of food for institutions, such as schools, hospitals, or cafeterias.
Prepare meals in private homes. Includes personal chefs.
Prepare, season, and cook dishes such as soups, meats, vegetables, or desserts in restaurants. May order supplies, keep records and accounts, price items on menu, or plan menu.
Prepare and cook to order a variety of foods that require only a short preparation time. May take orders from customers and serve patrons at counters or tables. Excludes Cooks, Fast Food (35-2011).
All cooks not listed separately.

SOC Code 35-2020 Food Preparation Workers are employees who engage in various food preparation tasks excluding cooking, such as slicing meat and shellfish, brewing beverages, and preparing cold dishes.
Perform a variety of food preparation duties other than cooking, such as preparing cold foods and shellfish, slicing meat, and brewing coffee or tea.

The SOC group 35-3020, Food and Beverage Serving Workers, encompasses individuals who primarily serve food and beverages to customers in various settings, including bartenders at bars and restaurants, fast food counter workers, waiters and waitresses at dining establishments excluding fast food, and non-restaurant food servers.
A bartender is an individual who prepares and serves alcoholic beverages to customers in various settings such as bars, restaurants, or hotels.
Mix and serve drinks to patrons, directly or through waitstaff.

SOC Code 35-3020 Fast Food and Counter Workers are employees who primarily take orders, serve food and beverages at counters or steam tables, handle payments, and may also prepare some items in fast-food establishments.

Perform duties such as taking orders and serving food and beverages. Serve customers at counter or from a steam table. May take payment. May prepare food and beverages. Counter attendants who also wait tables are included in Waiters and Waitresses (35-3031),
Waiters and Waitresses are restaurant employees responsible for taking orders and serving food and beverages to patrons at their tables, excluding fast food establishments.
Take orders and serve food and beverages to patrons at tables in dining establishment. Excludes Fast Food and Counter Workers (35-3023).

A Food Server in a Nonrestaurant setting is an individual who prepares and serves food to people outside traditional restaurant environments, such as in hotels, hospitals, or residential care facilities.

Serve food to individuals outside of a restaurant environment, such as in hotel rooms, hospital rooms, residential care facilities, or cars. Excludes Fast Food and Counter Workers (35-3023) and Door-to-Door Sales Workers, News and Street Vendors, and Related Workers (41-9091).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Other Food Preparation and Serving Related Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC group 35-9090, "Other Food Preparaion and Servicing Related Workers," encompasses various roles in food preparation and service not explicitly categorized elsewhere within the classification, including dinning room attendants, diswashers, hosts/hostesses, and other related occupations.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Dining Room and Cafeteria Attendants and Bartender Helpers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A dining room or cafeteria attendant is an individual who assists in food service by maintaining cleanliness, setting tables, replenishing supplies, and serving items such as water and coffee to patrons.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Dining Room and Cafeteria Attendants and Bartender Helpers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Facilitate food service. Clean tables; remove dirty dishes; replace soiled table linens; set tables; replenish supply of clean linens, silverware, glassware, and dishes; supply service bar with food; and serve items such as water, condiments, and coffee to patrons.
A "dishwasher" is an individual who specializes in cleaning and maintaining dishes, kitchen equipment, and utensils used in food preparation.
Clean dishes, kitchen, food preparation equipment, or utensils.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Hosts and Hostesses, Restaurant, Lounge, and Coffee Shop
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC 35-9030 refers to professionals who manage restaurant, lounge, and coffee shop operations by greeting customers, seating them appropriately, and maintaining high standards for both service and facilities.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Hosts and Hostesses, Restaurant, Lounge, and Coffee Shop
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Welcome patrons, seat them at tables or in lounge, and help ensure quality of facilities and service.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Food Preparation and Serving Related Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC group 35-9090, Broad Food Preparation and Serving Related Workers, encompasses all food preparation and serving roles not explicitly categorized elsewhere within the broader classification.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Food Preparation and Serving Related Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All food preparation and serving related workers not listed separately.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Building and Grounds Cleaning and Maintenance Occupations
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The Major group 37-0000 encompasses professionals in building and grounds cleaning and maintenance occupations, including supervisors overseeing cleaning personnel in various establishments, first-line supervisors of landscaping and groundskeeping workers, housekeeping staff, janitors, maids, peft control workers, groound maintenance workers, and all other building and ground cleaniers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Building and Grounds Cleaning and Maintenance Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A first-line supervisor who oversees and coordinates the work activities of building cleaning personnel, including housekeeping and grounds maintenance staff, ensuring efficient and effective operations in various establishments.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Building and Grounds Cleaning and Maintenance Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A first-line supervisor for building and grounds cleaning and maintenance workers who oversees and coordinates the work activities of housekeeping personnel in various establishments, as well as landscaping and groundskeeping staff.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Housekeeping and Janitorial Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate work activities of cleaning personnel in hotels, hospitals, offices, and other establishments.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Landscaping, Lawn Service, and Groundskeeping Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of workers engaged in landscaping or groundskeeping activities. Work may involve reviewing contracts to ascertain service, machine, and workforce requirements; answering inquiries from potential customers regarding methods, material, and price ranges; and preparing estimates according to labor, material, and machine costs.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Building Cleaning and Pest Control Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 37-2010 group includes professionals who specialize in various cleaning tasks within buildings, ranging from janitors and maids responsible for light to heavy cleaning duties, to pest control workers who eliminate infestations using chemical solutions or traps.

The SOC 37-2010 Building Cleaniing Workers group encompasses janitors and cleaners who perform various light to heavy cleaning tasks in a wide range of settings, including offices, schools, hospitals, hotels, and other establishments.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Janitors and Cleaners, Except Maids and Housekeeping Cleaners
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Keep buildings in clean and orderly condition. Perform heavy cleaning duties, such as cleaning floors, shampooing rugs, washing walls and glass, and removing rubbish. Duties may include tending furnace and boiler, performing routine maintenance activities, notifying management of need for repairs, and cleaning snow or debris from sidewalk.

Perform any combination of light cleaning duties to maintain private households or commercial establishments, such as hotels and hospitals, in a clean and orderly manner. Duties may include making beds, replenishing linens, cleaning rooms and halls, and vacuuming.
All building cleaning workers not listed separately.
Pest Control Workers are professionals who apply chemical solutions, release toxic gases, set traps, and use other methods to eliminate pests and vermin infesting buildings and surrounding areas.
Apply or release chemical solutions or toxic gases and set traps to kill or remove pests and vermin that infest buildings and surrounding areas.

Grogrounds Maintenance Workers are professionals responsible for various landscaping and groundkeeping tasks on properties, excluding specialized roles such as tree trimming, pesticide handling, and other specific categories.

Grogrounds Maintenance Workers are professionals who perform various tasks related to landscaping and groundkeeping, such as planting, pruning, mowing, fertilizing, and maintaining grounds using hand or power tools, excluding specialized roles like tree trimmers, pesticide handlers, and other specific categories.

Landscape or maintain grounds of property using hand or power tools or equipment. Workers typically perform a variety of tasks, which may include any combination of the following: sod laying, mowing, trimming, planting, watering, fertilizing, digging, raking, sprinkler installation, and installation of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units. Excludes Farmworkers and Laborers, Crop, Nursery, and Greenhouse (45-2092).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Pesticide Handlers, Sprayers, and Applicators, Vegetation
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Mix or apply pesticides, herbicides, fungicides, or insecticides through sprays, dusts, vapors, soil incorporation, or chemical application on trees, shrubs, lawns, or crops. Usually requires specific training and state or federal certification. Crop dusters are included in Commercial Pilots (53-2012).

Using sophisticated climbing and rigging techniques, cut away dead or excess branches from trees or shrubs to maintain right-of-way for roads, sidewalks, or utilities, or to improve appearance, health, and value of tree. Prune or treat trees or shrubs using handsaws, hand pruners, clippers, and power pruners. Works off the ground in the tree canopy and may use truck-mounted lifts. Excludes workers who primarily perform duties of Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers (37-3011) and Pesticide Handlers, Sprayers, and Applicators, Vegetation (37-3012).
All grounds maintenance workers not listed separately.

This occupational category includes various professionals who provide miscellaneous personal care and service tasks, such as childcare attendants, exercise instructors, recreation workers, residential advisors, and other similar roles that do not fall under specific categories within the personal care and service industry.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Personal Care and Service Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC group "Supervisors of Personal Care and Service Workers" (SOC Code 39-1000) refers to first-line supervisors who oversee various personal care and service workers, including those in entertainment, recreation, and other personal services, ensuring efficient coordination, guest satisfaction, and smooth operations.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Entertainment and Recreation Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC group 39-1010 refers to First-Line Supervisors of Entertainment and Recreation Workers who oversee various entertainment and recreational activities, including gaming services in casinos, ensuring smooth operations and guest satisfaction.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Gambling Services Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of workers in assigned gambling areas. May circulate among tables, observe operations, and ensure that stations and games are covered for each shift. May verify and pay off jackpots. May reset slot machines after payoffs and make repairs or adjustments to slot machines or recommend removal of slot machines for repair. May plan and organize activities and services for guests in hotels/casinos.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Entertainment and Recreation Workers, Except Gambling Services
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of entertainment and recreation related workers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Personal Service Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group "First-Line Supervisor of Personal Service Workers" (SOC Code 39-1020) refers to professionals who oversee and manage personal service workers, ensuring their activities are coordinated and efficient.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Personal Service Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Supervise and coordinate activities of personal service workers.

The SOC Group 39-2000 "Animal Care and Service Workers" encompasses professionals who specialize in training animals for various tasks such as security work, entertainment, or assisting people with disabilities, as well as those who provide comprehensive care and maintenance for pets and non-live stock animals in settings like kennels, animal shelters, zoos, and aquariums.

Animal Trainers are professionals who teach and condition various types of animals, such as dogs, horses, or birds, to perform specific tasks like security work, entertainment performances, assisting people with disabilities, or following commands for shows and competitions.

Train animals for riding, harness, security, performance, or obedience, or for assisting persons with disabilities. Accustom animals to human voice and contact, and condition animals to respond to commands. Train animals according to prescribed standards for show or competition. May train animals to carry pack loads or work as part of pack team.

The SOC Group 39-2020, "Animal Caretakers," refers to professionals who provide comprehensive care and maintenance for pets and non-livestock animals in various settings, excluding veterinary assistance and farmworkers.

Feed, water, groom, bathe, exercise, or otherwise provide care to promote and maintain the well-being of pets and other animals that are not raised for consumption, such as dogs, cats, race horses, ornamental fish or birds, zoo animals, and mice. Work in settings such as kennels, animal shelters, zoos, circuses, and aquariums. May keep records of feedings, treatments, and animals received or discharged. May clean, disinfect, and repair cages, pens, or fish tanks. Excludes Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers (31-9096) and Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals (45-2093).

The SOC Group 39-3010 "Entertainment Attendant" refers to professionals who provide assistance and support in various entertainment settings, including gamimg services, motion picture projection, and other miscellaneous tasks related to ensuring smooth operations and patron satisfaction.

The SOC group 39-3010, Gambling Services Workers, encompasses professionals involved in various aspects of gambling services, including operating table games, managing wagers and payments for patrons, and providing other related assistance.

Operate table games. Stand or sit behind table and operate games of chance by dispensing the appropriate number of cards or blocks to players, or operating other gambling equipment. Distribute winnings or collect players’ money or chips. May compare the house’s hand against players’ hands.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Gambling and Sports Book Writers and Runners
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Post information enabling patrons to wager on various races and sporting events. Assist in the operation of games such as keno and bingo. May operate random number-generating equipment and announce the numbers for patrons. Receive, verify, and record patrons’ wagers. Scan and process winning tickets presented by patrons and pay out winnings for those wagers.
All gambling service workers not listed separately.
A motion picture projectorist is an individual responsible for setting up, operating, and maintaining the equipment used to display films in cinemas or other large venues.
Set up and operate motion picture projection and related sound reproduction equipment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Ushers, Lobby Attendants, and Ticket Takers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Ushers, Lobby Attendantss, and Tiicket Takers are professionals who assist patrons at entertainment events by performing various tasks such as ticket collection, seating assistance, lost item search, and facility guidance.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Ushers, Lobby Attendants, and Ticket Takers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Assist patrons at entertainment events by performing duties, such as collecting admission tickets and passes from patrons, assisting in finding seats, searching for lost articles, and helping patrons locate such facilities as restrooms and telephones.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Entertainment Attendants and Related Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group encompasses various roles in the entertainment industry, including amusement attendant duties at recreational facilities, costume management for performers, and managing dressing rooms or coat check services.

Perform a variety of attending duties at amusement or recreation facility. May schedule use of recreation facilities, maintain and provide equipment to participants of sporting events or recreational pursuits, or operate amusement concessions and rides.
Select, fit, and take care of costumes for cast members, and aid entertainers. May assist with multiple costume changes during performances.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Locker Room, Coatroom, and Dressing Room Attendants
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Provide personal items to patrons or customers in locker rooms, dressing rooms, or coatrooms.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Entertainment Attendants and Related Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All entertainment attendants and related workers not listed separately.

SOC Group Definition: SOC Code 39-4000, Funeral Service Workers are professionals who prepare and handle deceased bodies for interment or cremation, ensuring compliance with legal requirements and state regulations, while also assisting in various tasks during funeral services.
Embalmers and Crematory Operators are professionals who prepare deceased bodies for interment or cremation, ensuring compliance with legal requirements, state regulations, and local customs.
Prepare bodies for interment in conformity with legal requirements.

Operate crematory equipment to reduce human or animal remains to bone fragments in accordance with state and local regulations. Duties may include preparing the body for cremation and performing general maintenance on crematory equipment. May use traditional flame-based cremation, calcination, or alkaline hydrolysis.
Funeral Attendant: A professional responsible for assisting with various tasks during funerals, including casquet placement, arranging offerings, and managing equipment.

Perform a variety of tasks during funeral, such as placing casket in parlor or chapel prior to service, arranging floral offerings or lights around casket, directing or escorting mourners, closing casket, and issuing and storing funeral equipment.

A Mortician, Undertaker, or Funeral Arranger is an individual responsible for planning and directing funeral services, including tasks such as body transportation coordination, detail arrangement with family members, and selection assistance for religious rituals.

Perform various tasks to arrange and direct individual funeral services, such as coordinating transportation of body to mortuary, interviewing family or other authorized person to arrange details, selecting pallbearers, aiding with the selection of officials for religious rites, and providing transportation for mourners. Excludes Funeral Home Managers (11-9171).

The SOC Group "Minor" with SOC Code 39-5000 refers to Personal Appearance Workers who offer a range of beauty and grooming services, including hair styling, makeup application, manicures, pedicures, and shampooing, excluding specific subcategories like Makeup Artists or Manicuriest.

Barbers, Hairstyle Traders, and Cosmetologist are professionals who offer various beauty services, including hair cutting, styling, coloring, and scalp treatments, as well as makeup application and nail care, excluding specific sub-categories like Makeup Artists or Manicuriest.
Provide barbering services, such as cutting, trimming, shampooing, and styling hair; trimming beards; or giving shaves.

Provide beauty services, such as cutting, coloring, and styling hair, and massaging and treating scalp. May shampoo hair, apply makeup, dress wigs, remove hair, and provide nail and skincare services. Excludes Makeup Artists, Theatrical and Performance (39-5091), Manicurists and Pedicurists (39-5092), and Skincare Specialists (39-5094).

Miscellaneous Personal Appearance Workers are professionals who provide various personal appearance services such as makeup application, manicures and pedicures, hair shampooing, and skincare treatments to enhance an individual's appearance.
Apply makeup to performers to reflect period, setting, and situation of their role.
Clean and shape customers’ fingernails and toenails. May polish or decorate nails.
Shampoo and rinse customers’ hair.
Provide skincare treatments to face and body to enhance an individual’s appearance. Includes electrologists and laser hair removal specialists.

A professional responsible for handling luggage at transportation hubs or providing personalized services to guests in various establishments, including bag porting, bellhopping, and concierge duties.
Baggage Porters, Bellhops, and Concierges are professionals who handle luggage for travelers at transportation hubs or provide personalized services to guests in various establishments.
Handle baggage for travelers at transportation terminals or for guests at hotels or similar establishments.

Assist patrons at hotel, apartment, or office building with personal services. May take messages; arrange or give advice on transportation, business services, or entertainment; or monitor guest requests for housekeeping and maintenance.
Tour and Travel Guide refers to professionals who lead sightseeing tours, escort individuals or groups through places of interest, and plan long-distance travels or expeditions.

SOC Code 39-7010 refers to Tour and Travel Guides who are responsible for leading sightseeing tours, escorting individuals or groups through places of interest, planning long-distance travels, and organizing expeditions.
Escort individuals or groups on sightseeing tours or through places of interest, such as industrial establishments, public buildings, and art galleries.
Plan, organize, and conduct long-distance travel, tours, and expeditions for individuals and groups.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Other Personal Care and Service Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC Group 39-9091 - This category encompasses professionals who provide various personal care and service tasks, such as childcare workers attending to children in different settings, exercise trainers designing fitness programs, recreation workers organizing activities for groups, residential advisors managing facilities and assisting residents, and other miscellaneous personal care and service roles not listed elsewhere.

Childcare Workers are professionals who attend to children in various settings such as schools, businesses, and childcare institutions, performing tasks like dressing, feeding, bathing, and supervising play activities.

Attend to children at schools, businesses, private households, and childcare institutions. Perform a variety of tasks, such as dressing, feeding, bathing, and overseeing play. Excludes Preschool Teachers, Except Special Education (25-2011) and Teaching Assistants, Preschool, Elementary, Middle, and Secondary School, Except Special Education (25-9042).
SOC Group 39-9030 Recreation and Fitness Workers are professionals who design, lead, and facilitate physical fitness programs for individuals or groups, excluding athletic coaching and training.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Exercise Trainers and Group Fitness Instructors
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Instruct or coach groups or individuals in exercise activities for the primary purpose of personal fitness. Demonstrate techniques and form, observe participants, and explain to them corrective measures necessary to improve their skills. Develop and implement individualized approaches to exercise. Excludes Educational Instruction and Library Occupations (25-0000), Coaches and Scouts (27-2022), and Athletic Trainers (29-9091).

Conduct recreation activities with groups in public, private, or volunteer agencies or recreation facilities. Organize and promote activities, such as arts and crafts, sports, games, music, dramatics, social recreation, camping, and hobbies, taking into account the needs and interests of individual members.

SOC Code 39-9040 - Residential Advvisors are professionals who manage daily operations in residential facilities such as dormitories and group homes, overseeing activities, supplies, maintenance, and assisting residents with various needs.

Coordinate activities in resident facilities in secondary school and college dormitories, group homes, or similar establishments. Order supplies and determine need for maintenance, repairs, and furnishings. May maintain household records and assign rooms. May assist residents with problem solving or refer them to counseling resources.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Personal Care and Service Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC Group 39-9090 refers to "Miscellaneous Personal Care and Service Workers," which encompasses various personal care and service occupations not listed under other specific categories within the same SOC group.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Personal Care and Service Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All personal care and service workers not listed separately.

Whole sale and manufacturing sales representatives are professionals who sell goods or services to wholesalers, manufacturers, or other businesses, requiring technical knowledge in specific fields such as bioengineering, electronics, engineering, chemistry, etc., or a broad understanding of various items for businesses.

SOC Group 41-1000, Supervisors of Sales Workers, encompasses first-line supervisors who oversee and coordinate sales activities in both retail and non-retail settings, handling tasks such as budgeting, accounting, and personnel management alongside their supervisory responsibilities.

The SOC Group 41-1010, First-Line Supervisor of Sales Workers, refers to supervisors who oversee and coordinate the activities of sales workers in retail or non-retail settings, often handling management tasks such as budgeting, accounting, and personnel work alongside their supervisory responsibilities.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Retail Sales Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of retail sales workers in an establishment or department. Duties may include management functions, such as purchasing, budgeting, accounting, and personnel work, in addition to supervisory duties.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Non-Retail Sales Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of sales workers other than retail sales workers. May perform duties such as budgeting, accounting, and personnel work, in addition to supervisory duties.

The SOC Group 41-2011 Retail Sales Workers includes professionals who handle financial transactions and sales in non-financial institutions, such as cashiers receiving and disbursing money using various methods, gambling change persons exchanging coins and tokens for patrons' money, and parts salespeople selling spare or replacement equipment.

Casheirers are professionals who handle financial transactions in non-financial institutions, utilizing various methods such as electronic scanners and cash registers to disburse money and process credit or debit card payments.

Receive and disburse money in establishments other than financial institutions. May use electronic scanners, cash registers, or related equipment. May process credit or debit card transactions and validate checks. Excludes Gambling Change Persons and Booth Cashiers (41-2012).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Gambling Change Persons and Booth Cashiers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Exchange coins, tokens, and chips for patrons’ money. May issue payoffs and obtain customer’s signature on receipt. May operate a booth in the slot machine area and furnish change persons with money bank at the start of the shift, or count and audit money in drawers. Excludes Cashiers (41-2011).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Counter and Rental Clerks and Parts Salespersons
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Counter and Rental Clerks and Parts Salesperson is an individual who either manages rental transactions, providing customers with repair services or selling parts for various items in a store setting.

Receive orders, generally in person, for repairs, rentals, and services. May describe available options, compute cost, and accept payment. Excludes Fast Food and Counter Workers (35-3023), Hotel, Motel, and Resort Desk Clerks (43-4081), Order Clerks (43-4151), and Reservation and Transportation Ticket Agents and Travel Clerks (43-4181).
Sell spare and replacement parts and equipment in repair shop or parts store.
A retail salesperson is an individual who sells various consumer goods, such as furniture, motor vehicles, appliances, or clothing, to customers in a non-depository financial institution setting.
Sell merchandise, such as furniture, motor vehicles, appliances, or apparel to consumers. Excludes Cashiers (41-2011).

A "Sales Representative, Services" is a professional who sells various services to individuals or businesses, excluding advertising, insurance, financial, and travel sectors, often describing options, resolving client problems, and may also include miscellaneous service-related roles.
Advertising Sales Agents are professionals who specialize in selling advertising space, time, or media across various platforms such as publications, signage, television, radio, and the internet.
Sell or solicit advertising space, time, or media in publications, signage, TV, radio, or Internet establishments or public spaces.

Insurance Sales Agents are professionals who sell various types of insurance policies, such as life, property, casualty, health, or automotive, and may work independently, refer clients to brokers, or be employed by insurance companies.
Sell life, property, casualty, health, automotive, or other types of insurance. May refer clients to independent brokers, work as an independent broker, or be employed by an insurance company.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Securities, Commodities, and Financial Services Sales Agents
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Securities, Commi... [The assistant continues to generate the response based on the user's request]

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Securities, Commodities, and Financial Services Sales Agents
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Buy and sell securities or commodities in investment and trading firms, or provide financial services to businesses and individuals. May advise customers about stocks, bonds, mutual funds, commodities, and market conditions.

A travel agent is a professional who assists individuals and organizations in planning and arranging transportation, accommodations, itineraries, and tour packages for various trips, ensuring smooth travel experiences.

Plan and sell transportation and accommodations for customers. Determine destination, modes of transportation, travel dates, costs, and accommodations required. May also describe, plan, and arrange itineraries and sell tour packages. May assist in resolving clients’ travel problems.
A Miscellaneous Sales Representative is an individual who sells various services to individuals or businesses, excluding advertising, insurance, financial, wholesale, and telemarketing sectors.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Sales Representatives of Services, Except Advertising, Insurance, Financial Services, and Travel
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Sell services to individuals or businesses. May describe options or resolve client problems. Excludes Advertising Sales Agents (41-3011), Insurance Sales Agents (41-3021), Securities, Commodities, and Financial Services Sales Agents (41-3031), Travel Agents (41-3041), Sales Representatives, Wholesale and Manufacturing (41-4010), and Telemarketers (41-9041).

SOC Group 41-4000, Sales Representatives in Wholesale and Manufacturing, encompasses professionals who sell goods to wholesalers or manufacturers, requiring technical knowledge for specific products like bioengineering or electronics, or a broad understanding of various items for businesses or groups.

Sales Representatives in Wholesale and Manufacturing are professionals who sell goods to wholesalers or manufacturers, either requiring technical knowledge for specific products like bioengineering or electronics, or a broad understanding of various items for businesses or groups.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Sales Representatives, Wholesale and Manufacturing, Technical and Scientific Products
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Sell goods for wholesalers or manufacturers where technical or scientific knowledge is required in such areas as biology, engineering, chemistry, and electronics, normally obtained from at least 2 years of postsecondary education. Excludes Sales Engineers (41-9031).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Sales Representatives, Wholesale and Manufacturing, Except Technical and Scientific Products
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Sell goods for wholesalers or manufacturers to businesses or groups of individuals. Work requires substantial knowledge of items sold.

The SOC Group 41-9090 "Other Sales and Related Workers" encompasses professionals who demonstrate products or models to generate interest, answer questions about them, sell demonstrated items if applicable, work as real estate brokers overseeing transactions, act as sales agents renting or buying properties for clients, operate as telemarketers soliciting orders via telephone, and engage in various other sales-related roles not specified elsewhere.

This SOC group encompasses professionals who showcase products or models to generate interest and promote sales, including demonstrators who exhibit and explain merchandise, product promoters who create public interest in buying products, and models who display garments and accessories for potential buyers.
Demonstrate merchandise and answer questions for the purpose of creating public interest in buying the product. May sell demonstrated merchandise.

Model garments or other apparel and accessories for prospective buyers at fashion shows, private showings, or retail establishments. May pose for photos to be used in magazines or advertisements. May pose as subject for paintings, sculptures, and other types of artistic expression.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Real Estate Brokers and Sales Agents
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group Broad 41-9020 refers to Real Estate Brokers and Sales Agents who oversee real estate transactions, sell or rent properties for clients, and assist in property sales contracts.
Operate real estate office, or work for commercial real estate firm, overseeing real estate transactions. Other duties usually include selling real estate or renting properties and arranging loans.

Rent, buy, or sell property for clients. Perform duties such as study property listings, interview prospective clients, accompany clients to property site, discuss conditions of sale, and draw up real estate contracts. Includes agents who represent buyer.

Sales Engineers are professionals who combine technical expertise equivalent to a baccalaureate degree in engineering with marketing and sales skills to promote and sell complex business goods or services.

Sell business goods or services, the selling of which requires a technical background equivalent to a baccalaureate degree in engineering. Excludes Engineers (17-2011 through 17-2199) whose primary function is not marketing or sales.
Telemarketers are professionals who solicit orders or donations for goods and services through telephone communication.
Solicit donations or orders for goods or services over the telephone.

The SOC Group 41-9090, "Miscellaneous Sales and Related Workers," refers to a broad occupational category encompassing various sales roles, including door-to-door and street sales workers who sell goods or services directly to customers, as well as other unspecified sales and related positions.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Door-to-Door Sales Workers, News and Street Vendors, and Related Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Sell goods or services door-to-door or on the street.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Sales and Related Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All sales and related workers not listed separately.

This occupational category encompasses various roles in desktop publishing, insurance claims processing, mail handling, office administration, proofreading and statistical analysis, all of which contribute to the efficient functioning of an organization but do not fall under specific subcategories.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Office and Administrative Support Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The role of Supervisor(s) of Office and Administrative Support Workers involves overseeing and coordinating the tasks and responsibilities of clerical and administrative staff to ensure efficient office operations.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Office and Administrative Support Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: First-Line Supervisor of Office and Administrative Support Workers: An individual who oversees and manages the tasks and responsibilities of clerical and administrative support staff, ensuring efficient operations within an office environment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Office and Administrative Support Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of clerical and administrative support workers.

The SOC Group 43-2000 "Communications Equipment Operators" refers to professionals who manage and operate various communication equipment, including switchboards, to relay calls, provide information, handle special requests, and assist individuals with making teleponecalls.

A Switchboard Operator, including Answering Service, is an individual who manages telephone business systems equipment to relay incoming, outgoing, and interoffice calls, while also providing information to callers and recording messages as needed.
Operate telephone business systems equipment or switchboards to relay incoming, outgoing, and interoffice calls. May supply information to callers and record messages.

Telephone operators are professionals who provide information by accessing various directories and assist customers with special billings requests, emergency calls, and support for individuals requiring assistance in making telephone calls.

Provide information by accessing alphabetical, geographical, or other directories. Assist customers with special billing requests, such as charges to a third party and credits or refunds for incorrectly dialed numbers or bad connections. May handle emergency calls and assist children or people with physical disabilities to make telephone calls.

The SOC Group "Broad 43-2090 Miscellaneous Communications Equipment Operators" refers to professionals who operate various types of communication equipment not explicitly categorized under other specific communication operator roles.
All communications equipment operators not listed separately.

Financial Clerks are professionals responsible for handling various administrative tasks related to financial transactions and records management within an organization, excluding specific roles such as bookkeeping, billing, procurement, and miscellaneous financial clerks.

Bill and Account Collectors are professionals responsible for locating customers with delinquent accounts through various communication methods, soliciting payment, managing account records, and initiating repossession or service disconnection procedures if necessary.

Locate and notify customers of delinquent accounts by mail, telephone, or personal visit to solicit payment. Duties include receiving payment and posting amount to customer’s account, preparing statements to credit department if customer fails to respond, initiating repossession proceedings or service disconnection, and keeping records of collection and status of accounts.

SOC Group 43-3020 Billing and Posting Clerks are responsible for compiling, computing, and recording numerical data related to billing, including preparing invoices for services rendered or goods delivered, excluding medical record keeping.

Compile, compute, and record billing, accounting, statistical, and other numerical data for billing purposes. Prepare billing invoices for services rendered or for delivery or shipment of goods. Excludes Medical Records Specialists (29-2072).

A Bookkeeping, Accounting, and Auditing Clerk is responsible for maintaining accurate financial records by performing tasks such as data entry, calculation verification, and ensuring the accuracy of financial transactions.

Compute, classify, and record numerical data to keep financial records complete. Perform any combination of routine calculating, posting, and verifying duties to obtain primary financial data for use in maintaining accounting records. May also check the accuracy of figures, calculations, and postings pertaining to business transactions recorded by other workers. Excludes Payroll and Timekeeping Clerks (43-3051).

A Gambling Cafe Worker is an individual who manages financial transactions in a gambling establishment, including accepting credit applications, reconciling accounts, and handling casino chips or tickets for patrons.

In a gambling establishment, conduct financial transactions for patrons. Accept patron’s credit application and verify credit references to provide check-cashing authorization or to establish house credit accounts. May reconcile daily summaries of transactions to balance books. May sell gambling chips, tokens, or tickets to patrons, or to other workers for resale to patrons. May convert gambling chips, tokens, or tickets to currency upon patron’s request. May use a cash register or computer to record transaction.

Payroll and Timekeeping Clerks are responsible for compiling and recording employee time data, computing pay rates, wages, deductions, and may also prepare paychecks, excluding broader bookkeeping, accounting, and auditing tasks.
