Compile and record employee time and payroll data. May compute employees’ time worked, production, and commission. May compute and post wages and deductions, or prepare paychecks. Excludes Bookkeeping, Accounting, and Auditing Clerks (43-3031).

The SOC Group 43-3060 "Procurement Clerks" are professionals responsible for gathering and organizing data to create purchase orders for materials and services, excluding those related to wholesale or retail buying, except for farm products.
Compile information and records to draw up purchase orders for procurement of materials and services. Excludes Wholesale and Retail Buyers, Except Farm Products (13-1022).
Tellers are professionals who manage monetary transactions at financial institutions, including handling cash, deposits, and withdrawals, while maintaining accurate records of these activities.
Receive and pay out money. Keep records of money and negotiable instruments involved in a financial institution’s various transactions.
A "Financial Clerk" in the SOC Group 43-3090 is responsible for handling various administrative tasks related to financial transactions and records management within an organization.
All financial clerks not listed separately.

A "Miscellaneous Information and Record Clerk" is an individual responsible for managing various types of information and records across different industries, not specifically categorized within other clerical roles.

A Brokerage Clerk is a professional who performs various tasks related to securities transactions, including writing orders for stock purchases or sales, computing transfer taxes and equity, verifying transactions, tracking stock prices, distributing dividends, and maintaining records of daily transactions and holdings.

Perform duties related to the purchase, sale, or holding of securities. Duties include writing orders for stock purchases or sales, computing transfer taxes, verifying stock transactions, accepting and delivering securities, tracking stock price fluctuations, computing equity, distributing dividends, and keeping records of daily transactions and holdings.

A Correspondence Clerk is an administrative professional responsible for drafting letters or electronic communications in response to various requests and issues related to merchandise, damage claims, credit inquiries, delinquent accounts, billing errors, and service complaints.

Compose letters or electronic correspondence in reply to requests for merchandise, damage claims, credit and other information, delinquent accounts, incorrect billings, or unsatisfactory services. Duties may include gathering data to formulate reply and preparing correspondence.

Court, Municipal, and License Clerks refer to professionals who perform various clerical tasks for courts, municipalities, or government agencies, including drafting documents, managing records, issuing licenses, and supporting administrative functions.

Perform clerical duties for courts of law, municipalities, or governmental licensing agencies and bureaus. May prepare docket of cases to be called; secure information for judges and court; prepare draft agendas or bylaws for town or city council; answer official correspondence; keep fiscal records and accounts; issue licenses or permits; and record data, administer tests, or collect fees. Clerks of Court are classified in Managers, All Other (11-9199).
Credit Authorizers, Checkers, and Clearkes are professionals responsible for evaluating and approving credit applications, assessing customer creditworthiness, and processing transactions.

Authorize credit charges against customers’ accounts. Investigate history and credit standing of individuals or business establishments applying for credit. May interview applicants to obtain personal and financial data, determine credit worthiness, process applications, and notify customers of acceptance or rejection of credit.

SOC 43-4050 Broad Cuostoer Service Representatives are professionals who primarily engage with customers to provide basic or scripted information about products and services, handle routine inquiries, resolve general complaints, excluding installation, sales, repair, and technical support tasks.

Interact with customers to provide basic or scripted information in response to routine inquiries about products and services. May handle and resolve general complaints. Excludes individuals whose duties are primarily installation, sales, repair, and technical support.
A role responsible for assessing applicants' eligibility to receive assistance from various government programs, such as welfare, unemployment benefits, social security, and public housing.
Determine eligibility of persons applying to receive assistance from government programs and agency resources, such as welfare, unemployment benefits, social security, and public housing.

SOC Group 43-4070 File Clerks are professionals responsible for managing and organizing various types of files, such as correspondence, cards, invoices, receipts, and other records, in alphabetical or numerical order based on the specific filing system used.
File correspondence, cards, invoices, receipts, and other records in alphabetical or numerical order or according to the filing system used. Locate and remove material from file when requested.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Hotel, Motel, and Resort Desk Clerks
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Hotel, Motel, and Resort Desk Clerks are professionals who manage guest check-ins and check-outs at hotels, motels, and resorts, handling tasks such as room assignments, communication with guests, record keeping, reservation management, and payment collection.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Hotel, Motel, and Resort Desk Clerks
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Accommodate hotel, motel, and resort patrons by registering and assigning rooms to guests, issuing room keys or cards, transmitting and receiving messages, keeping records of occupied rooms and guests’ accounts, making and confirming reservations, and presenting statements to and collecting payments from departing guests.
Interviewers who collect data by conducting interviews through various methods such as phone, mail, in-person, or other means, and assist with form completion, sorting, classification, and filing.

Interview persons by telephone, mail, in person, or by other means for the purpose of completing forms, applications, or questionnaires. Ask specific questions, record answers, and assist persons with completing form. May sort, classify, and file forms.

A library assistant, clerical is an individual responsible for managing and organizing various library materials such as books, electronic media, and artwork, while also assisting patrons with their inquiries and handling circulation tasks.

Compile records, and sort, shelve, issue, and receive library materials such as books, electronic media, pictures, cards, slides and microfilm. Locate library materials for loan and replace material in shelving area, stacks, or files according to identification number and title. Register patrons to permit them to borrow books, periodicals, and other library materials. Excludes Library Technicians (25-4031).

A Loan Interviewer and Clerk is an individual responsible for interviewing loan applicants to gather necessary information, verifying their backgrounds, preparing loan request documents, and managing transactions related to approved loans.

Interview loan applicants to elicit information; investigate applicants’ backgrounds and verify references; prepare loan request papers; and forward findings, reports, and documents to appraisal department. Review loan papers to ensure completeness, and complete transactions between loan establishment, borrowers, and sellers upon approval of loan.

A New Accounts Cleark is an individual who interviews potential clients for financial institutions, explaining available account services and assisting them in completing applications to open new accounts.
Interview persons desiring to open accounts in financial institutions. Explain account services available to prospective customers and assist them in preparing applications.

SOC Group 43-4150 Order Clerks are professionals responsible for receiving, processing, and managing various orders related to materials, merchandise, services, or classified ads through multiple communication channels, excluding dispatchers.

Receive and process incoming orders for materials, merchandise, classified ads, or services such as repairs, installations, or rental of facilities. Generally receives orders via mail, phone, fax, or other electronic means. Duties include informing customers of receipt, prices, shipping dates, and delays; preparing contracts; and handling complaints. Excludes Dispatchers, Except Police, Fire, and Ambulance (43-5032) who both dispatch and take orders for services.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Human Resources Assistants, Except Payroll and Timekeeping
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Human Resources Assistant (Except Payroll and Timekeeping) is an individual responsible for managing employee records, including compiling data such as addresses, earnings, absences, and termination details, while excluding payroll and timekeeping tasks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Human Resources Assistants, Except Payroll and Timekeeping
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Compile and keep personnel records. Record data for each employee, such as address, weekly earnings, absences, amount of sales or production, supervisory reports, and date of and reason for termination. May prepare reports for employment records, file employment records, or search employee files and furnish information to authorized persons.

Recepitionists and Information Clerks are professionals who manage inquiries and provide essential information to various stakeholders about an organization's activities, locations, and personnel, excluding switchboard operators.

Answer inquiries and provide information to the general public, customers, visitors, and other interested parties regarding activities conducted at establishment and location of departments, offices, and employees within the organization. Excludes Switchboard Operators, Including Answering Service (43-2011).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Reservation and Transportation Ticket Agents and Travel Clerks
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Reservation and Transportation Ticket Agents and Travel Clerks are professionals responsible for handling reservations for various transportation modes or lodging facilities, excluding those who primarily sell travel packages, work as cashiers, travel agents, or hotel clerks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Reservation and Transportation Ticket Agents and Travel Clerks
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Make and confirm reservations for transportation or lodging, or sell transportation tickets. May check baggage and direct passengers to designated concourse, pier, or track; deliver tickets and contact individuals and groups to inform them of package tours; or provide tourists with travel or transportation information. Excludes Cashiers (41-2011), Travel Agents (41-3041), and Hotel, Motel, and Resort Desk Clerks (43-4081) who sell tickets for local transportation.
The "Miscellaneous Information and Record Clerks" SOC group (43-4190) encompasses professionals who manage various types of information and records not categorized elsewhere in clerical roles.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Information and Record Clerks, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All information and record clerks not listed separately.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Material Recording, Scheduling, Dispatching, and Distributing Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 43-5070 "Shipping, Receiving, and Inventory Clerks" are professionals responsible for verifying, recording, and managing incoming and outgoing shipments, as well as maintaining inventory records, excluding tasks related to weighing or measuring.

SOC Group Broad 43-5010 Cargo and Freiht Agent: A professional responsible for managing the logistics of cargo and freight shipments, including expediting, routing, and coordinating pickup and delivery in various transportation hubs.

Expedite and route movement of incoming and outgoing cargo and freight shipments in airline, train, and trucking terminals and shipping docks. Take orders from customers and arrange pickup of freight and cargo for delivery to loading platform. Prepare and examine bills of lading to determine shipping charges and tariffs.

Courers and Messengers are individuals who transport messages, documents, packages, or other items between offices, departments, or businesses using various modes of transportation such as foot, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile, or public conveyance.

Pick up and deliver messages, documents, packages, and other items between offices or departments within an establishment or directly to other business concerns, traveling by foot, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile, or public conveyance. Excludes Light Truck Drivers (53-3033).

A dispatcher is an individual who manages communications and coordinates resources for emergency response or service delivery operations across various sectors, including public safety and transportation.

Operate telephone, radio, or other communication systems to receive and communicate requests for emergency assistance at 9-1-1 public safety answering points and emergency operations centers. Take information from the public and other sources regarding crimes, threats, disturbances, acts of terrorism, fires, medical emergencies, and other public safety matters. May coordinate and provide information to law enforcement and emergency response personnel. May access sensitive databases and other information sources as needed. May provide additional instructions to callers based on knowledge of and certification in law enforcement, fire, or emergency medical procedures.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Dispatchers, Except Police, Fire, and Ambulance
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Schedule and dispatch workers, work crews, equipment, or service vehicles for conveyance of materials, freight, or passengers, or for normal installation, service, or emergency repairs rendered outside the place of business. Duties may include using radio, telephone, or computer to transmit assignments and compiling statistics and reports on work progress.
Meter Readers, Utilities are professionals who measure and record the usage of utilities such as electricity, gas, water, or steam for billing purposes.
Read meter and record consumption of electricity, gas, water, or steam.
A role within the postal service sector that involves handling, sorting, processing, and distributing mail for the United States Postal Service (USPS) or its contractors.

Perform any combination of tasks in a United States Postal Service (USPS) post office, such as receive letters and parcels; sell postage and revenue stamps, postal cards, and stamped envelopes; fill out and sell money orders; place mail in pigeon holes of mail rack or in bags; and examine mail for correct postage. Includes postal service clerks employed by USPS contractors.
Sort and deliver mail for the United States Postal Service (USPS). Deliver mail on established route by vehicle or on foot. Includes postal service mail carriers employed by USPS contractors.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Postal Service Mail Sorters, Processors, and Processing Machine Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Prepare incoming and outgoing mail for distribution for the United States Postal Service (USPS). Examine, sort, and route mail. Load, operate, and occasionally adjust and repair mail processing, sorting, and canceling machinery. Keep records of shipments, pouches, and sacks, and perform other duties related to mail handling within the postal service. Includes postal service mail sorters and processors employed by USPS contractors. Excludes Postal Service Clerks (43-5051) and Postal Service Mail Carriers (43-5052).

The SOC group 43-5060 refers to Production, Planning and Expediting Clerks who manage and coordinate work schedules, materials flow, and production progress within or between departments, excluding project management specialists and recordkeeping roles.

Coordinate and expedite the flow of work and materials within or between departments of an establishment according to production schedule. Duties include reviewing and distributing production, work, and shipment schedules; conferring with department supervisors to determine progress of work and completion dates; and compiling reports on progress of work, inventory levels, costs, and production problems. Excludes Project Management Specialists (13-1082) and Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping (43-5111).

SOC Group 43-5070 refers to Shipping, Receiving, and Inventoy Clerks who are responsible for verifying, recording, and managing incoming and outgoing shipments, excluding specific duties related to weighing, measuring, or stocking.

Verify and maintain records on incoming and outgoing shipments involving inventory. Duties include verifying and recording incoming merchandise or material and arranging for the transportation of products. May prepare items for shipment. Excludes Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping (43-5111), Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, except Postal Service (43-9051), and Stockers and Order Fillers (53-7065).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A SOC 43-5110 occupation involves clerical duties focused on weighing, measuring, and checking various materials and equipment for recordkeeping purposes, excluding tasks performed by inspectors or testers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Weigh, measure, and check materials, supplies, and equipment for the purpose of keeping relevant records. Duties are primarily clerical by nature. Includes workers who collect and keep record of samples of products or materials. Excludes Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers (51-9061).

Secretary and Administrative Assistant is an occupational category encompassing professionals who provide essential administrative support in various industries, handling tasks such as research, correspondence preparation, scheduling, and specialized duties tailored to specific settings like legal, medical, or executive levels.

The SOC code 43-6010 refers to secretaries and administrative assistants who provide essential administrative support in various settings, handling tasks such as research, correspondence preparation, scheduling, and specialized duties tailored to specific industries like legal, medical, or executive levels.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Executive Secretaries and Executive Administrative Assistants
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Provide high-level administrative support by conducting research, preparing statistical reports, and handling information requests, as well as performing routine administrative functions such as preparing correspondence, receiving visitors, arranging conference calls, and scheduling meetings. May also train and supervise lower-level clerical staff. Excludes Secretaries (43-6012 through 43-6014).

Perform secretarial duties using legal terminology, procedures, and documents. Prepare legal papers and correspondence, such as summonses, complaints, motions, and subpoenas. May also assist with legal research.

Perform secretarial duties using specific knowledge of medical terminology and hospital, clinic, or laboratory procedures. Duties may include scheduling appointments, billing patients, and compiling and recording medical charts, reports, and correspondence.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, Except Legal, Medical, and Executive
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Perform routine administrative functions such as drafting correspondence, scheduling appointments, organizing and maintaining paper and electronic files, or providing information to callers. Excludes legal, medical, and executive secretaries (43-6011 through 43-6013).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Other Office and Administrative Support Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC Group 43-9190 refers to a diverse range of office and administrative support roles that encompass various tasks such as data entry, proofreading, mail handling, statistical analysis, and other miscellaneous duties not specifically categorized under the subcatetories.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Data Entry and Information Processing Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Data Entry and Information Processing Workers are professionals who manage data entry tasks using various devices like keyboards or photo composing perfometers, encompassing roles such as Data Entry Keyers who verify data for printing materials and Word Processors and Typists who type letters, reports, and other materials from drafts or voice recordings.
Operate data entry device, such as keyboard or photo composing perforator. Duties may include verifying data and preparing materials for printing. Excludes Word Processors and Typists (43-9022).

Use word processor, computer, or typewriter to type letters, reports, forms, or other material from rough draft, corrected copy, or voice recording. May perform other clerical duties as assigned. Excludes Court Reporters and Simultaneous Captioners (27-3092), Medical Transcriptionists (31-9094), Secretaries and Administrative Assistants (43-6010), and Data Entry Keyers (43-9021).
Desktop publishers are professionals who utilize specialized software to design and format textual and graphical elements for various publications.
Format typescript and graphic elements using computer software to produce publication-ready material.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Insurance Claims and Policy Processing Clerks
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC 43-9040 refers to insurance professionals who process and handle policy claims, including verifying information from policyholders, updating records, and processing new policies or modifications.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Insurance Claims and Policy Processing Clerks
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Process new insurance policies, modifications to existing policies, and claims forms. Obtain information from policyholders to verify the accuracy and completeness of information on claims forms, applications and related documents, and company records. Update existing policies and company records to reflect changes requested by policyholders and insurance company representatives. Excludes Claims Adjusters, Examiners, and Investigators (13-1031).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Mail Clekrs and Mail Machine Operator (except Postal Service) is an employee responsible for handling mail operations in non-postal settings, including sorting, distributing, and processing incoming and outgoing correspondence.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Prepare incoming and outgoing mail for distribution. Time-stamp, open, read, sort, and route incoming mail; and address, seal, stamp, fold, stuff, and affix postage to outgoing mail or packages. Duties may also include keeping necessary records and completed forms.

SOC Group 43-9060, Office Clerks, General refers to employees who perform diverse and varied clerical duties in an office setting, requiring knowledge of office systems and procedures, and may include tasks such as answering phones, bookkeeping, typing or word processing, operating office machines, and filing.

Perform duties too varied and diverse to be classified in any specific office clerical occupation, requiring knowledge of office systems and procedures. Clerical duties may be assigned in accordance with the office procedures of individual establishments and may include a combination of answering telephones, bookkeeping, typing or word processing, office machine operation, and filing.

A "Office Machine Operator, Except Computer" is an individual responsible for operating various office machines, such as photocopiers, photo processors, and duplicators, excluding those related to billing, posting, or postal services.

Operate one or more of a variety of office machines, such as photocopying, photographic, and duplicating machines, or other office machines. Excludes Billing and Posting Clerks (43-3021) and Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service (43-9051).

Proofreaders and Copy Markers are professionals who meticulously review written materials, such as transcripts or proofs, to identify and correct any errors in grammar, spelling, punctuation, or composition, while excluding those whose primary role is editing.

Read transcript or proof type setup to detect and mark for correction any grammatical, typographical, or compositional errors. Excludes workers whose primary duty is editing copy. Includes proofreaders of braille.
A Statistical Assistant is a professional who compiles and computes data using statistical formulas for studies, potentially including actuarial work such as actuarial computation.

Compile and compute data according to statistical formulas for use in statistical studies. May perform actuarial computations and compile charts and graphs for use by actuaries. Includes actuarial clerks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Office and Administrative Support Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 43-9190, "Miscellaneous Office and Administrative Support Workers," refers to a broad category encompassing various office and administrative support roles not listed under other specific subcategories.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Office and Administrative Support Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All office and administrative support workers not listed separately.

This occupational category refers to individuals who are involved in various aspects of forestry and conservation work, including raising seedlings, combating harmful insects, building structures for erosion control, logging operations such as felling trees and operating logging equipment, and other related tasks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 45-1010 refers to First-Line Supervisor of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers who are responsible for overseeing and managing agricultural, aquaculture, and forestry workers in their daily tasks, excluding those involved in landscaping, lawn service, or groundkeeping.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 45-1010 refers to First-Line Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers who are responsible for directly overseeing and managing agricultural, aquaculture, and forestry workers in their day-to-day operations.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of agricultural, forestry, aquacultural, and related workers. Excludes First-Line Supervisors of Landscaping, Lawn Service, and Groundskeeping Workers (37-1012).

The SOC code 45-2019 encompasses Agricultural Workers who perform a wide range of tasks related to crop and animal production, including grading, sorting, inspecting, and breeding agricultural products and animals.
Agricultural Inspectors are professionals who inspect agricultural products, processing equipment, and facilities to ensure compliance with health, quality, safety regulations.
Inspect agricultural commodities, processing equipment, and facilities, and fish and logging operations, to ensure compliance with regulations and laws governing health, quality, and safety.

A professional who specializes in selecting and mating animals based on their genetic traits, characteristics, and offspring production, requiring knowledge of artificial insemination techniques and record-keeping.

Select and breed animals according to their genealogy, characteristics, and offspring. May require knowledge of artificial insemination techniques and equipment use. May involve keeping records on heats, birth intervals, or pedigree. Excludes Animal Scientists (19-1011) whose primary function is research and Animal Caretakers (39-2021) who may occasionally breed animals as part of their other caretaking duties.

Graders and Sorters, Agricultural Products are professionals who classify unprocessed food and other agricultural products based on specific criteria such as size, weight, color, or condition, excluding those who inspect these products.
Grade, sort, or classify unprocessed food and other agricultural products by size, weight, color, or condition. Excludes Agricultural Inspectors (45-2011).

Agricultural Workers in this SOC group perform various tasks related to crop and animal production, including operating agricultural equipment, manually handling crops, tending to animals, and engaging in miscellaneous agricultural activities not specified elsewhere.

Drive and control equipment to support agricultural activities such as tilling soil; planting, cultivating, and harvesting crops; feeding and herding livestock; or removing animal waste. May perform tasks such as crop baling or hay bucking. May operate stationary equipment to perform post-harvest tasks such as husking, shelling, threshing, and ginning.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Farmworkers and Laborers, Crop, Nursery, and Greenhouse
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Manually plant, cultivate, and harvest vegetables, fruits, nuts, horticultural specialties, and field crops. Use hand tools, such as shovels, trowels, hoes, tampers, pruning hooks, shears, and knives. Duties may include tilling soil and applying fertilizers; transplanting, weeding, thinning, or pruning crops; applying pesticides; or cleaning, grading, sorting, packing, and loading harvested products. May construct trellises, repair fences and farm buildings, or participate in irrigation activities. Excludes Pesticide Handlers, Sprayers, and Applicators, Vegetation (37-3012), Graders and Sorters, Agricultural Products (45-2041), and Forest, Conservation, and Logging Workers (45-4011 through 45-4029).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Attend to live farm, ranch, open range or aquacultural animals that may include cattle, sheep, swine, goats, horses and other equines, poultry, rabbits, finfish, shellfish, and bees. Attend to animals produced for animal products, such as meat, fur, skins, feathers, eggs, milk, and honey. Duties may include feeding, watering, herding, grazing, milking, castrating, branding, de-beaking, weighing, catching, and loading animals. May maintain records on animals; examine animals to detect diseases and injuries; assist in birth deliveries; and administer medications, vaccinations, or insecticides as appropriate. May clean and maintain animal housing areas. Includes workers who shear wool from sheep and collect eggs in hatcheries.
All agricultural workers not listed separately.

Fishing and Hunting Workers are individuals who engage in activities such as hunting, trapping, catching, or gathering wild animals or aquatic plants using various equipment, excluding those working on fish farms.

Fishing and Hunting Workers are individuals who engage in activities such as hunting, trapping, catching, or gathering wild animals or aquatic plants using various equipment, excluding those working on fish farms.

Hunt, trap, catch, or gather wild animals or aquatic animals and plants. May use nets, traps, or other equipment. May haul catch onto ship or other vessel. Aquacultural laborers who work on fish farms are included in Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals (45-2093).

The SOC group 45-4000, Forest and Conservation Workers, encompasses individuals who perform manual labor under supervision to develop, maintain, or protect natural areas such as forests, wetlands, and woodlands through activities like raising seedlings, combating harmful insects, building structures, and controlling erosion.

Forest and Conservation Workers are individuals who perform manual labor under supervision to develop, maintain, or protect natural areas such as forests, wetlands, and woodlands through activities like raising and transporting seedlings, combating harmful insects and diseases, and building structures to control water and erosion.

Under supervision, perform manual labor necessary to develop, maintain, or protect areas such as forests, forested areas, woodlands, wetlands, and rangelands through such activities as raising and transporting seedlings; combating insects, pests, and diseases harmful to plant life; and building structures to control water, erosion, and leaching of soil. Includes forester aides, seedling pullers, tree planters, and gatherers of nontimber forestry products such as pine straw.

The SOC 45-4020 occupational group consists of Logging Workers who are responsible for various tasks in tree harvesting and log processing, including falling trees, operating logging equipment, grading logs, and other related activities.
Use axes or chainsaws to fell trees using knowledge of tree characteristics and cutting techniques to control direction of fall and minimize tree damage.

Drive logging tractor or wheeled vehicle equipped with one or more accessories, such as bulldozer blade, frontal shear, grapple, logging arch, cable winches, hoisting rack, or crane boom, to fell tree; to skid, load, unload, or stack logs; or to pull stumps or clear brush. Includes operating stand-alone logging machines, such as log chippers. Logging truck drivers are included in Heavy and Tractor-Trailer Truck Drivers (53-3032).

Grade logs or estimate the marketable content or value of logs or pulpwood in sorting yards, millpond, log deck, or similar locations. Inspect logs for defects or measure logs to determine volume. Excludes Buyers and Purchasing Agents, Farm Products (13-1021).
All logging workers not listed separately.
Underground and surface mining machine operators who specialize in various aspects of extractive industries, including excavation, loading, drilling, explosives handling, and support services.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Construction and Extraction Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A First-Line Supervisor of Construction Trade and Extraction Workers is an individual who directly manages and coordinates the tasks and activities of construction or extraction workers within a company.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Construction Trades and Extraction Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A First-Line Supervisor of Construction Trade and Extraction Workers is an individual responsible for directly managing and coordinating the tasks and activities of construction or extraction workers within a company.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Construction Trades and Extraction Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of construction or extraction workers.

A professional who specializes in installing, maintaining, and repairing various types of pipes, plumbing systems, heating, ventilation, and air conditionation (HVAC) equipment, excluding tasks such as welding or soldering.

A boilermaker is a skilled tradesperson who constructs, assembles, maintains, and repairs stationary steam boilers and their auxiliaries, using various tools and techniques to ensure safe and efficient operation.

Construct, assemble, maintain, and repair stationary steam boilers and boiler house auxiliaries. Align structures or plate sections to assemble boiler frame tanks or vats, following blueprints. Work involves use of hand and power tools, plumb bobs, levels, wedges, dogs, or turnbuckles. Assist in testing assembled vessels. Direct cleaning of boilers and boiler furnaces. Inspect and repair boiler fittings, such as safety valves, regulators, automatic-control mechanisms, water columns, and auxiliary machines.

The SOC Group 47-2020 refers to professionals who specialize in constructing or repairing structures using various building materials like brick, structural tile, concrete block, glass block, and terra-cotta blocks.

Lay and bind building materials, such as brick, structural tile, concrete block, cinder block, glass block, and terra-cotta block, with mortar and other substances, to construct or repair walls, partitions, arches, sewers, and other structures. Installers of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units are classified in Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers (37-3011). Excludes Stonemasons (47-2022).
Build stone structures, such as piers, walls, and abutments. Lay walks, curbstones, or special types of masonry for vats, tanks, and floors.

A carpenter is a skilled tradesperson who specializes in constructing, repairing, and installing wooden structures, fixtures, and components using various materials such as wood, concrete forms, and insulation products.

Construct, erect, install, or repair structures and fixtures made of wood and comparable materials, such as concrete forms; building frameworks, including partitions, joists, studding, and rafters; and wood stairways, window and door frames, and hardwood floors. May also install cabinets, siding, drywall, and batt or roll insulation. Includes brattice builders who build doors or brattices (ventilation walls or partitions) in underground passageways.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Carpet, Floor, and Tile Installers and Finishers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Carpet, Floor, and Tile Installers and Finishers are professionals who specialize in laying carpet or tile flooring materials on various surfaces, excluding wood and hard tiles installation, and may also involve finishing touches such as sanding and sealing.
Lay and install carpet from rolls or blocks on floors. Install padding and trim flooring materials. Excludes Floor Layers, Except Carpet, Wood, and Hard Tiles (47-2042).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Floor Layers, Except Carpet, Wood, and Hard Tiles
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Apply blocks, strips, or sheets of shock-absorbing, sound-deadening, or decorative coverings to floors.
Scrape and sand wooden floors to smooth surfaces using floor scraper and floor sanding machine, and apply coats of finish.
Apply hard tile, stone, and comparable materials to walls, floors, ceilings, countertops, and roof decks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Cement Masons, Concrete Finishers, and Terrazzo Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Cement Masons, Concrete Finishers, and Terrazzo Workers (SOC 47-2050) are skilled tradespeople who specialize in smoothing and finishing concrete surfaces using various tools and techniques, including applying decorative terrazzotone finishes to floors, stairways, and other structures.

Smooth and finish surfaces of poured concrete, such as floors, walks, sidewalks, roads, or curbs using a variety of hand and power tools. Align forms for sidewalks, curbs, or gutters; patch voids; and use saws to cut expansion joints. Installers of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units are classified in Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers (37-3011).
Apply a mixture of cement, sand, pigment, or marble chips to floors, stairways, and cabinet fixtures to fashion durable and decorative surfaces.

Construction laborers are workers who perform various physical tasks at construction sites, using hand and power tools to assist in site preparation, excavation, scaffolding erection, and waste cleanup, excluding those specializing in hazardous materials removal.

Perform tasks involving physical labor at construction sites. May operate hand and power tools of all types: air hammers, earth tampers, cement mixers, small mechanical hoists, surveying and measuring equipment, and a variety of other equipment and instruments. May clean and prepare sites, dig trenches, set braces to support the sides of excavations, erect scaffolding, and clean up rubble, debris, and other waste materials. May assist other craft workers. Construction laborers who primarily assist a particular craft worker are classified under Helpers, Construction Trades (47-3010). Excludes Hazardous Materials Removal Workers (47-4041).

The SOC Group 47-2070 Broad Construction Equipment Operaors is an occupational category that encompasses individuals who operate various types of construction equipment, including paving and tampering machinery, pilers for structures, and other powered construction vehicles used in earth excavation, grading, structure erection, and hard surface pavement pouring.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Paving, Surfacing, and Tamping Equipment Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate equipment used for applying concrete, asphalt, or other materials to road beds, parking lots, or airport runways and taxiways or for tamping gravel, dirt, or other materials. Includes concrete and asphalt paving machine operators, form tampers, tamping machine operators, and stone spreader operators.

Operate pile drivers mounted on skids, barges, crawler treads, or locomotive cranes to drive pilings for retaining walls, bulkheads, and foundations of structures such as buildings, bridges, and piers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Operating Engineers and Other Construction Equipment Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate one or several types of power construction equipment, such as motor graders, bulldozers, scrapers, compressors, pumps, derricks, shovels, tractors, or front-end loaders to excavate, move, and grade earth, erect structures, or pour concrete or other hard surface pavement. May repair and maintain equipment in addition to other duties. Excludes Extraction Workers (47-5000) and Crane and Tower Operators (53-7021).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Drywall Installers, Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 47-2080 refers to skilled professionals who specialize in installing decorative wall coverings such as plaster, applying soundproof materials to walls and ceilings, or creating seamless joints between plasterboard surfaces for further finishing.

Apply plasterboard or other wallboard to ceilings or interior walls of buildings. Apply or mount acoustical tiles or blocks, strips, or sheets of shock-absorbing materials to ceilings and walls of buildings to reduce or reflect sound. Materials may be of decorative quality. Includes lathers who fasten wooden, metal, or rockboard lath to walls, ceilings, or partitions of buildings to provide support base for plaster, fireproofing, or acoustical material. Excludes Carpenters (47-2031), Carpet Installers (47-2041), and Tile and Stone Setters (47-2044).
Seal joints between plasterboard or other wallboard to prepare wall surface for painting or papering.

Electricians are professionals who specialize in installing, maintaining, and repairing electrical wiring, equipment, and fixtures, ensuring compliance with relevant codes while excluding security and fire alarm systems.

Install, maintain, and repair electrical wiring, equipment, and fixtures. Ensure that work is in accordance with relevant codes. May install or service street lights, intercom systems, or electrical control systems. Excludes Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installers (49-2098).
Glaziers are professionals who specialize in installing glass products for various applications, including windows, doors, skylights, and interior/exterior surfaces.
Install glass in windows, skylights, store fronts, and display cases, or on surfaces, such as building fronts, interior walls, ceilings, and tabletops.

Insulation Workers are professionals who specialize in applying insulating materials to various structures, such as floors, ceilings, walls, and mechanical systems like pipes or ductwork, to regulate temperature and improve energy efficiency.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Insulation Workers, Floor, Ceiling, and Wall
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Line and cover structures with insulating materials. May work with batt, roll, or blown insulation materials.
Apply insulating materials to pipes or ductwork, or other mechanical systems in order to help control and maintain temperature.

Painters and Paperhangers are skilled workers who specialize in painting structural surfaces such as walls, equipment, and buildings with brushes, rollers, or spray guns, while also covering interior surfaces with decorative wallpaper or fabric for aesthetic purposes.

Paint walls, equipment, buildings, bridges, and other structural surfaces, using brushes, rollers, and spray guns. May remove old paint to prepare surface prior to painting. May mix colors or oils to obtain desired color or consistency. Excludes Paperhangers (47-2142).

Cover interior walls or ceilings of rooms with decorative wallpaper or fabric, or attach advertising posters on surfaces such as walls and billboards. May remove old materials or prepare surfaces to be papered.

Pipelayers, Plumber, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters are professionals who specialize in installing, assembling, altering, repairing, and maintaining various types of pipes and pipe systems that transport water, steam, gases, or other liquids, including the installation of heating equipment and mechanical control systems.

Lay pipe for storm or sanitation sewers, drains, and water mains. Perform any combination of the following tasks: grade trenches or culverts, position pipe, or seal joints. Excludes Welders, Cutters, Solderers, and Brazers (51-4121).

Assemble, install, alter, and repair pipelines or pipe systems that carry water, steam, air, or other liquids or gases. May install heating and cooling equipment and mechanical control systems. Includes sprinkler fitters.
Plasterers and Stucco Mason are skilled workers who specialize in applying decorative plaster materials such as plaister or stucco to interior or exterior surfaces.
Apply interior or exterior plaster, cement, stucco, or similar materials. May also set ornamental plaster.
Reinforcing Iron and Rebar Workers are skilled laborers who install steel bars or mesh in concrete forms to strengthen structures during construction projects.
Position and secure steel bars or mesh in concrete forms in order to reinforce concrete. Use a variety of fasteners, rod-bending machines, blowtorches, and hand tools. Includes rod busters.
A roofer is an individual responsible for installing and repairing roofs on various types of structures using materials such as shingles, slate, aluminum, or wood.

Cover roofs of structures with shingles, slate, asphalt, aluminum, wood, or related materials. May spray roofs, sidings, and walls with material to bind, seal, insulate, or soundproof sections of structures.

A Sheet Metal Worker is an individual who specializes in fabricating, assembling, installing, and repairing various sheet metal products and equipment, such as ducts, control boxes, and furnace casings, using techniques like cutting, bending, shaping, soldering, and welding.

Fabricate, assemble, install, and repair sheet metal products and equipment, such as ducts, control boxes, drainpipes, and furnace casings. Work may involve any of the following: setting up and operating fabricating machines to cut, bend, and straighten sheet metal; shaping metal over anvils, blocks, or forms using hammer; operating soldering and welding equipment to join sheet metal parts; or inspecting, assembling, and smoothing seams and joints of burred surfaces. Includes sheet metal duct installers who install prefabricated sheet metal ducts used for heating, air conditioning, or other purposes.

Structural Iron and Steel Workers are professionals who specialize in raising, positioning, and joining iron or steel beams, columns, and other structural components to construct buildings, bridges, and other structures, excluding reinforcing iron work.

Raise, place, and unite iron or steel girders, columns, and other structural members to form completed structures or structural frameworks. May erect metal storage tanks and assemble prefabricated metal buildings. Excludes Reinforcing Iron and Rebar Workers (47-2171).

A Solar Photovoltaic Installer is a professional who specializes in assembling, installing, and maintaining solar photovoltaic (PV) systems on structures, ensuring compliance with site assessments and schematics, while excluding certain electrical and thermal tasks.

Assemble, install, or maintain solar photovoltaic (PV) systems on roofs or other structures in compliance with site assessment and schematics. May include measuring, cutting, assembling, and bolting structural framing and solar modules. May perform minor electrical work such as current checks. Excludes solar PV electricians who are included in Electricians (47-2111) and solar thermal installers who are included in Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters (47-2152).

The SOC Group 47-3000, or "Helpers--Construction Trade," refers to individuals who assist skilled construction trade workers in various capacities requiring less skill than their counterparts, such as bricklayers, carpenters, electricians, painters, plumbers, and roofers.

This SOC group encompasses various helpers in the construction trades who perform duties requiring less skill than their respective skilled trade counterparts, including but not limited to bricklayers, carpenters, electricians, painters, plumbers, and roofers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Helpers--Brickmasons, Blockmasons, Stonemasons, and Tile and Marble Setters
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Help brickmasons, blockmasons, stonemasons, or tile and marble setters by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist brickmasons, blockmasons, and stonemasons or tile and marble setters are classified under Construction Laborers (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help carpenters by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist carpenters are classified under Construction Laborers (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help electricians by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist electricians are classified under Construction Laborers (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Helpers--Painters, Paperhangers, Plasterers, and Stucco Masons
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Help painters, paperhangers, plasterers, or stucco masons by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist painters, paperhangers, plasterers, or stucco masons are classified under Construction Laborers (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help plumbers, pipefitters, steamfitters, or pipelayers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist plumbers, pipefitters, steamfitters, or pipelayers are classified under Construction Laborers (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help roofers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist roofers are classified under Construction Laborers (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
All construction trades helpers not listed separately.

This SOC group encompasses professionals engaged in various miscellaneous tasks within the construction industry, including inspecting structures for compliance with regulations, installing and maintaining elevators and escalators, erecting fences, removing hazardous materials, repairing highways, laying railroad tracks, cleaning septic tanks and sewers, and other related tasks not covered by specific subcategories.

A Construction and Building Inspector is an individual who utilizes engineering expertise to assess structures for structural integrity, adherence to specifications, building codes, and other regulations through general or specialized inspections.

Inspect structures using engineering skills to determine structural soundness and compliance with specifications, building codes, and other regulations. Inspections may be general in nature or may be limited to a specific area, such as electrical systems or plumbing.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Elevator and Escalator Installers and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A professional who specializes in assembling, installing, repairing, and maintaining various types of elevators and escalators for freight or passenger transportation.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Elevator and Escalator Installers and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Assemble, install, repair, or maintain electric or hydraulic freight or passenger elevators, escalators, or dumbwaiters.
Fence Erectors are professionals who specialize in installing, constructing, repairing, and maintaining various types of fences and gates using both manual and power tools.
Erect and repair fences and fence gates, using hand and power tools.

Hazardous Materials Removal Workers are specialized professionals who identify, remove, and safely dispose of hazardous materials such as asbestos, lead-based paint, and radioactive substances, requiring specific training and certification in handling these dangerous materials.

Identify, remove, pack, transport, or dispose of hazardous materials, including asbestos, lead-based paint, waste oil, fuel, transmission fluid, radioactive materials, or contaminated soil. Specialized training and certification in hazardous materials handling or a confined entry permit are generally required. May operate earth-moving equipment or trucks.

Highway Maintenance Workers are responsible for maintaining and repairing various types of roads, including highways, municipal and rural roads, airport runways, and rights-of-way, by performing tasks such as patching pavement, fixing guard rails, and clearing snow.

Maintain highways, municipal and rural roads, airport runways, and rights-of-way. Duties include patching broken or eroded pavement and repairing guard rails, highway markers, and snow fences. May also mow or clear brush from along road, or plow snow from roadway. Excludes Tree Trimmers and Pruners (37-3013).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Rail-Track Laying and Maintenance Equipment Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Rail-Track Laying and Maintenance Equipment Operators are professionals responsible for laying, repairing, and maintaining tracks using specialized equipment for standard or narrow-gauge railroad systems in various settings such as plant yards, mines, and quarries.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Rail-Track Laying and Maintenance Equipment Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Lay, repair, and maintain track for standard or narrow-gauge railroad equipment used in regular railroad service or in plant yards, quarries, sand and gravel pits, and mines. Includes ballast cleaning machine operators and railroad bed tamping machine operators.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Septic Tank Servicers and Sewer Pipe Cleaners
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Septic Tank Serviceors and Sewer Pipe Cleaneers are professionals who specialize in cleaning, repairing, and maintaining septic tanks, sewer lines, and drains, ensuring their proper functioning.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Septic Tank Servicers and Sewer Pipe Cleaners
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Clean and repair septic tanks, sewer lines, or drains. May patch walls and partitions of tank, replace damaged drain tile, or repair breaks in underground piping.

The SOC 47-4090 code represents miscellaneous construction and related workers who are involved in various tasks such as laying out, cutting, and placing segmental pavement units, including the installation of bedding and restraining materials for these units.
Lay out, cut, and place segmental paving units. Includes installers of bedding and restraining materials for the paving units.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Construction and Related Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All construction and related workers not listed separately.

The SOC Group 47-5090 "Extraction Workers" refers to professionals engaged in various extractive activities, including oil and gas extraction, surface and underground mining, explosives handling, earth drilling, rock splitting, and other related tasks not classified under specific occupations within the broader industry.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Derrick, Rotary Drill, and Service Unit Operators, Oil and Gas
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Derrick, Rotary Drill, and Service Unit Operator in Oil and Gas is responsible for operating various equipment involved in oil and gas extraction, including drilling rigs to remove underground resources or core samples, setting up and maintaining derricks, and using service units to increase oil flow or remove obstructions from wells.
Rig derrick equipment and operate pumps to circulate mud or fluid through drill hole.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Rotary Drill Operators, Oil and Gas
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up or operate a variety of drills to remove underground oil and gas, or remove core samples for testing during oil and gas exploration. Excludes Earth Drillers, Except Oil and Gas (47-5023).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Service Unit Operators, Oil and Gas
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate equipment to increase oil flow from producing wells or to remove stuck pipe, casing, tools, or other obstructions from drilling wells. Includes fishing-tool technicians.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Surface Mining Machine Operators and Earth Drillers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Surface Mining Machine Operators and Earth Drillers are professionals who operate various types of machinery in surface mining operations, including equipment for excavating and loading loose materials such as coal or gravel, as well as drilling machines used to extract core samples, tap subsurface water sources, or facilitate the use of explosives in construction projects.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Excavating and Loading Machine and Dragline Operators, Surface Mining
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend machinery at surface mining site, equipped with scoops, shovels, or buckets to excavate and load loose materials.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Earth Drillers, Except Oil and Gas
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate a variety of drills such as rotary, churn, and pneumatic to tap subsurface water and salt deposits, to remove core samples during mineral exploration or soil testing, and to facilitate the use of explosives in mining or construction. Includes horizontal and earth boring machine operators.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Explosives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Exploives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters are professionals who handle, place, and detonate explosives for various purposes such as demolishing structures or moving earth and rock materials.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Explosives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Place and detonate explosives to demolish structures or to loosen, remove, or displace earth, rock, or other materials. May perform specialized handling, storage, and accounting procedures.
Underground Mining Machine Operators are professionals who operate various types of machinery in underground mining environments to extract and transport materials such as coal, ore, rock, or sand.
Operate self-propelled mining machines that rip coal, metal and nonmetal ores, rock, stone, or sand from the mine face and load it onto conveyors, shuttle cars, or trucks in a continuous operation.
Operate machinery to install roof support bolts in underground mine.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Loading and Moving Machine Operators, Underground Mining
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate underground loading or moving machine to load or move core, ore, or rock using shuttle or mine car or conveyors. Equipment may include power shovels, hoisting engines equipped with cable-drawn scraper or scoop, or machines equipped with gathering arms and conveyor.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Underground Mining Machine Operators, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All underground mining machine operators not listed separately.
A Rock Splitter, Quarry worker is an individual who specializes in separating blocks of rough dimension stone from quarry masses using tools like jackhammers, wedges, or chopping saws.
Separate blocks of rough dimension stone from quarry mass using jackhammers, wedges, or chop saws.
The SOC Group 47-5070 Roustabouts, Oil and Gas occupation involves assembling or repairing oil field equipment using various tools and performing related tasks as required in the oil industry.
Assemble or repair oil field equipment using hand and power tools. Perform other tasks as needed.

The SOC group "Broad - Helpers -- Extraction Workers" refers to workers who assist less skilled extraction craft workers in their duties, such as supplying equipment or cleaning work areas, but do not have enough expertise to be classified under specific skill-based categories.

Help extraction craft workers, such as earth drillers, blasters and explosives workers, derrick operators, and mining machine operators, by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include supplying equipment or cleaning work area. Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
SOC Group Broad 47-5090 Miscellaneous Extraction Workers are individuals engaged in various extraction activities not classified under specific occupations within the broader extraction industry.
All extraction workers not listed separately.

This occupational category encompasses professionals who specialize in repairing various types of equipment and machinery, including but not limited to musical instruments, watches, clocks, wind turbines, amusement machines, and other miscellaneous installation, maintenance, and repair tasks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 49-1000 Supervisor role involves overseeing and coordinating the tasks of mechanics, installers, and repair workers, excluding team leaders, with responsibilities including direct supervision, coordination, and customer advice on recommended services.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: First-Line Supervisor of Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers: A role responsible for overseeing and coordinating the tasks of mechanics, installers, and repair workers, excluding team or work leaders.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of mechanics, installers, and repairers. May also advise customers on recommended services. Excludes team or work leaders.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Electrical and Electronic Equipment Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Electric and Electronic Equipment Installers and Repairers are professionals who specialize in installing, maintaining, repairing, and adjusting various types of computer systems, office equipment, telecommunication devices, radio transmitters, broadcasting equipment, avionic systems (excluding line installation tasks), and miscellaneous electronic equipment across different industries.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Computer, Automated Teller, and Office Machine Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Computer, Automated Tellter, and Office Machine Reparees are professionals who specialize in repairing, maintaining, and installing various types of computer systems, automated teller machines (ATMs), and electronic office equipment such as duplicators and fax machines.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Computer, Automated Teller, and Office Machine Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Repair, maintain, or install computers, word processing systems, automated teller machines, and electronic office machines, such as duplicating and fax machines.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Radio and Telecommunications Equipment Installers and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Radio and Telecommunications Equipment Installers and Repairers are skilled professionals who install, maintain, and repair various radio, telecommunication, and mobile communication equipment, excluding line installation tasks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Radio, Cellular, and Tower Equipment Installers and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Repair, install, or maintain mobile or stationary radio transmitting, broadcasting, and receiving equipment, and two-way radio communications systems used in cellular telecommunications, mobile broadband, ship-to-shore, aircraft-to-ground communications, and radio equipment in service and emergency vehicles. May test and analyze network coverage.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Telecommunications Equipment Installers and Repairers, Except Line Installers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Install, set up, rearrange, or remove switching, distribution, routing, and dialing equipment used in central offices or headends. Service or repair telephone, cable television, Internet, and other communications equipment on customers’ property. May install communications equipment or communications wiring in buildings. Excludes Telecommunications Line Installers and Repairers (49-9052).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Electrical and Electronic Equipment Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Miscellaneous Electrical and Electronic Equipment Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers encompasses professionals who specialize in repairing, installing, or maintaining various electrical and electronic equipment across different industries, excluding avionics technicians and other specific subcategories within this group.
Install, inspect, test, adjust, or repair avionics equipment, such as radar, radio, navigation, and missile control systems in aircraft or space vehicles.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Electric Motor, Power Tool, and Related Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Repair, maintain, or install electric motors, wiring, or switches.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers, Transportation Equipment
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Install, adjust, or maintain mobile electronics communication equipment, including sound, sonar, security, navigation, and surveillance systems on trains, watercraft, or other mobile equipment. Excludes Avionics Technicians (49-2091) and Electronic Equipment Installers and Repairers, Motor Vehicles (49-2096).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Electrical and Electronics Repairers, Commercial and Industrial Equipment
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Repair, test, adjust, or install electronic equipment, such as industrial controls, transmitters, and antennas. Excludes Avionics Technicians (49-2091), Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers, Transportation Equipment (49-2093), and Electronic Equipment Installers and Repairers, Motor Vehicles (49-2096).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Electrical and Electronics Repairers, Powerhouse, Substation, and Relay
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Inspect, test, repair, or maintain electrical equipment in generating stations, substations, and in-service relays.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Electronic Equipment Installers and Repairers, Motor Vehicles
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Install, diagnose, or repair communications, sound, security, or navigation equipment in motor vehicles.

Install, repair, or adjust audio or television receivers, stereo systems, camcorders, video systems, or other electronic entertainment equipment in homes or other venues. May perform routine maintenance. Excludes Audio and Video Technicians (27-4011).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Install, program, maintain, and repair security and fire alarm wiring and equipment. Ensure that work is in accordance with relevant codes. Excludes Electricians (47-2111) who do a broad range of electrical wiring.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A professional specializing in diagnosing, repairing, adjusting, or overhauling various types of vehicles, mobile equipment, and related machinery, excluding specific subcategories such as automotive glass installers, airframe technicians, bus mechanics, truck mechanics, and others mentioned in the context.
Aircraft Mechanics and Service Technicians are professionals who specialize in diagnosing, repairing, adjusting, or overhauling aircraft engines and assemblies, excluding avionic systems.
Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul aircraft engines and assemblies, such as hydraulic and pneumatic systems. Excludes Avionics Technicians (49-2091).

Automotiive Technicians and Reparees are professionals who specialize in diagnosing, repairing, and maintaining various aspects of automotive vehicles, excluding specific subcategories like Automobile Body and Related Repairers (49-3021) and Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists (49-3031).

Repair and refinish automotive vehicle bodies and straighten vehicle frames. Excludes Automotive Glass Installers and Repairers (49-3022) and Coating, Painting, and Spraying Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders (51-9124).
Replace or repair broken windshields and window glass in motor vehicles.

Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul automotive vehicles. Excludes Automotive Body and Related Repairers (49-3021), Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists (49-3031), and Electronic Equipment Installers and Repairers, Motor Vehicles (49-2096).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Broad SOC Group 49-3030: Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists are professionals who diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul buses and trucks, as well as maintain and repair various types of diesel engines, including those used in automobiles and marine vessels.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul buses and trucks, or maintain and repair any type of diesel engines. Includes mechanics working primarily with automobile or marine diesel engines.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians and Mechanics
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians and Mechanics are professionals who specialize in diagnosing, adjusting, repairing, or overhauling various types of heavy machinery and vehicles, excluding buses, trucks, diesel engines, and rail cars.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Farm Equipment Mechanics and Service Technicians
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul farm machinery and vehicles, such as tractors, harvesters, dairy equipment, and irrigation systems. Excludes Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists (49-3031).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Mobile Heavy Equipment Mechanics, Except Engines
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul mobile mechanical, hydraulic, and pneumatic equipment, such as cranes, bulldozers, graders, and conveyors, used in construction, logging, and mining. Excludes Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists (49-3031) and Rail Car Repairers (49-3043).
Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul railroad rolling stock, mine cars, or mass transit rail cars. Excludes Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists (49-3031).

The SOC Group 49-3050 Small Engine Mechanics is an occupational category for professionals who specialize in diagnosing, adjusting, repairing, and overhauling small engines used in various applications such as motorboats, motorcycles, outdoor power equipment, and other related machinery.
Repair and adjust electrical and mechanical equipment of inboard or inboard-outboard boat engines. Excludes Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists (49-3031).
Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul motorcycles, scooters, mopeds, dirt bikes, or similar motorized vehicles.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Outdoor Power Equipment and Other Small Engine Mechanics
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul small engines used to power lawn mowers, chain saws, recreational sporting equipment, and related equipment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Miscellaneous Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Mechanics, Installers, and Repairers is an individual who specializes in repairing and maintaining a variety of vehicles and mobile equipment, including bike mechanics for bicycles and recreational vehicle service technicians with expertise in diagnosing, adjusting, and overhauling components specific to recreational vehicles.
Repair and service bicycles.

Diagnose, inspect, adjust, repair, or overhaul recreational vehicles including travel trailers. May specialize in maintaining gas, electrical, hydraulic, plumbing, or chassis/towing systems as well as repairing generators, appliances, and interior components. Includes workers who perform customized van conversions. Excludes Automotive Service Technicians and Mechanics (49-3023) and Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists (49-3031) who also work on recreation vehicles.
Repair and replace tires.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Other Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Occupations
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This occupational category encompasses professionals who specialize in various aspects of maintaining and repairing equipment, including watchmaking, clock repair, wind turbine maintenance, amusement machine servicing, commercial diving, locksmith work, mobile home installation, signal system maintenance, and other miscellaneous installation, maintenance, and repair tasks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Control and Valve Installers and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Control and Valve Installers and Repairers are professionals who specialize in installing, repairing, and maintaining various mechanical devices, including control systems like gas regulators, safety valves, thermostats, and other similar equipment, excluding automatic door mechanisms.
Install, service, or repair automatic door mechanisms and hydraulic doors. Includes garage door mechanics.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Control and Valve Installers and Repairers, Except Mechanical Door
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Install, repair, and maintain mechanical regulating and controlling devices, such as electric meters, gas regulators, thermostats, safety and flow valves, and other mechanical governors.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers is a professional who specializes in installing, maintaining, and repairing heating, ventilation, air conditioning (HVAC), and refridgeration systems.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Install or repair heating, central air conditioning, HVAC, or refrigeration systems, including oil burners, hot-air furnaces, and heating stoves.

A Home Appliance Repairer is an individual who specializes in repairing, adjusting, or installing various types of household appliances, including electric and gas-powered devices such as refrigerators, washers, dryers, and ovens.
Repair, adjust, or install all types of electric or gas household appliances, such as refrigerators, washers, dryers, and ovens.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Industrial Machinery Installation, Repair, and Maintenance Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 49-9040 includes industrial machine repair workers who specialize in installing, adjusting, and maintaining various types of machinery used in production processes, excluding those related to mobile heavy equipment or general maintenance.

Repair, install, adjust, or maintain industrial production and processing machinery or refinery and pipeline distribution systems. May also install, dismantle, or move machinery and heavy equipment according to plans. Excludes Mobile Heavy Equipment Mechanics, Except Engines (49-3042), and Maintenance Workers, Machinery (49-9043).
Lubricate machinery, change parts, or perform other routine machinery maintenance. Excludes Maintenance and Repair Workers, General (49-9071).
Install, dismantle, or move machinery and heavy equipment according to layout plans, blueprints, or other drawings.
Build or repair equipment such as furnaces, kilns, cupolas, boilers, converters, ladles, soaking pits, and ovens, using refractory materials.

Line installers and repairers are professionals who specialize in installing or maintaining various types of cables and wires used in electric power distribution systems or telecommunications networks.

Install or repair cables or wires used in electrical power or distribution systems. May erect poles and light or heavy duty transmission towers. Excludes Electrical and Electronics Repairers, Powerhouse, Substation, and Relay (49-2095).
Install and repair telecommunications cable, including fiber optics.

Precision Instrument and Equipment Repairers are professionals who specialize in repairing and maintaining various precision instruments and equipment, including cameras, medical devices, musical instruments (excluding electric/electronic ones), watches, clocks, and other unspecified precision tools.
Repair and adjust cameras and photographic equipment, including commercial video and motion picture camera equipment.
Test, adjust, or repair biomedical or electromedical equipment.

Repair percussion, stringed, reed, or wind instruments. May specialize in one area, such as piano tuning. Excludes Audiovisual Equipment Installers and Repairers (49-2097) who repair electrical and electronic musical instruments.

Repair, clean, and adjust mechanisms of timing instruments, such as watches and clocks. Includes watchmakers, watch technicians, and mechanical timepiece repairers. Excludes Timing Device Assemblers and Adjusters (51-2061).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Precision Instrument and Equipment Repairers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All precision instrument and equipment repairers not listed separately.

Maintenance and Repair Workers, General are skilled professionals who perform various maintenance tasks involving multiple occupational skills to repair, maintain, and install machinery, equipment, and structures in buildings.

Perform work involving the skills of two or more maintenance or craft occupations to keep machines, mechanical equipment, or the structure of a building in repair. Duties may involve pipe fitting; HVAC maintenance; insulating; welding; machining; carpentry; repairing electrical or mechanical equipment; installing, aligning, and balancing new equipment; and repairing buildings, floors, or stairs.
