Excludes Facilities Managers (11-3013) and Maintenance Workers, Machinery (49-9043).

A Wind Turbine Service Technician is a professional responsible for inspecting, diagnosing, adjusting, and repairing wind turbines, ensuring their proper functioning by addressing electrical, mechanical, and hydraulic issues.
Inspect, diagnose, adjust, or repair wind turbines. Perform maintenance on wind turbine equipment including resolving electrical, mechanical, and hydraulic malfunctions.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 49-9090 encompasses miscellaneous installation, maintenance, and repair workers who perform various tasks such as servicing amusement machines, commercial diving, locksmith work, rigging, mobile home installation, signalling systems maintenance, and other unspecified installation, maintenance, and repair jobs.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Coin, Vending, and Amusement Machine Servicers and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Install, service, adjust, or repair coin, vending, or amusement machines including video games, juke boxes, pinball machines, or slot machines.

Work below surface of water, using surface-supplied air or scuba equipment to inspect, repair, remove, or install equipment and structures. May use a variety of power and hand tools, such as drills, sledgehammers, torches, and welding equipment. May conduct tests or experiments, rig explosives, or photograph structures or marine life. Excludes Athletes and Sports Competitors (27-2021), Police and Sheriff’s Patrol Officers (33-3051), and Fishing and Hunting Workers (45-3031).
Repair and open locks, make keys, change locks and safe combinations, and install and repair safes.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Manufactured Building and Mobile Home Installers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Move or install mobile homes or prefabricated buildings.
Set up or repair rigging for construction projects, manufacturing plants, logging yards, ships and shipyards, or for the entertainment industry.
Install, inspect, test, maintain, or repair electric gate crossings, signals, signal equipment, track switches, section lines, or intercommunications systems within a railroad system.

Help installation, maintenance, and repair workers in maintenance, parts replacement, and repair of vehicles, industrial machinery, and electrical and electronic equipment. Perform duties such as furnishing tools, materials, and supplies to other workers; cleaning work area, machines, and tools; and holding materials or tools for other workers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All installation, maintenance, and repair workers not listed separately.

This occupational category refers to individuals who perform various tasks in production processes, excluding those listed under specific categories like Photographic Process Workers and Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators, and including roles such as paper goods machine operators, etchers, and miscellaneous production workers.
A Supervisor of Production Workers is an individual responsible for overseeing and coordinating the tasks of production and operating workers, excluding team or work leaders, in various industries.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Production and Operating Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The "First-Line Supervisor of Production and Operating Workers" is an occupational category that involves directly supervising and coordinating the activities of production and operating workers, excluding team or work leaders.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Production and Operating Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of production and operating workers, such as inspectors, precision workers, machine setters and operators, assemblers, fabricators, and plant and system operators. Excludes team or work leaders.

SOC 51-2090: A broad occupational category encompassing various professionals who assemble or fabricate products and components as part of a team, often with rotating tasks within the assembly process, not separately classified in other categories.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Aircraft Structure, Surfaces, Rigging, and Systems Assemblers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition:
SOC Group: Broad

SOC Code: 51-2010

SOC Title: Aircraft Structucture, Surfaces, Rigging, and Systems Assemblers - Professionals responsible for assembling various components of aircrafts, space vehicles, or missiles, including but not limited to wings, fuselages, stabilizers, landing gear, and heating systems.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Aircraft Structure, Surfaces, Rigging, and Systems Assemblers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Assemble, fit, fasten, and install parts of airplanes, space vehicles, or missiles, such as tails, wings, fuselage, bulkheads, stabilizers, landing gear, rigging and control equipment, or heating and ventilating systems.

The SOC Group 51-2020 Broad occupational category includes workers who assemble, modify, or repair electrical and electronic components, equipment, and devices, such as winders, finishers, assemblers, and technicians in various electric and electronics industries.

Wind wire coils used in electrical components, such as resistors and transformers, and in electrical equipment and instruments, such as field cores, bobbins, armature cores, electrical motors, generators, and control equipment.
Assemble or modify electrical or electronic equipment, such as computers, test equipment telemetering systems, electric motors, and batteries.
Assemble or modify electromechanical equipment or devices, such as servomechanisms, gyros, dynamometers, magnetic drums, tape drives, brakes, control linkage, actuators, and appliances.

SOC Group 51-2030 refers to Engine and Other Machine Assemblers who construct, assemble, or rebuild various types of machinery, such as engines and turbines, used in industries like construction, extraction, textiles, and paper manufacturing.
Construct, assemble, or rebuild machines, such as engines, turbines, and similar equipment used in such industries as construction, extraction, textiles, and paper manufacturing.
SOC Group 51-2040 refers to Structural Metal Fabricators and Fitters who specialize in creating, positioning, aligning, and assembling components for structural metal products, excluding shipfitters.
Fabricate, position, align, and fit parts of structural metal products. Shipfitters are included in Layout Workers, Metal and Plastic (51-4192).

SOC 51-2050 Fiberglass Laminaotrs and Fabricaors are professionals who specialize in laminating layers of fiberglass onto molds to create components for various products such as boat decks, golf cart bodies, and automobile parts.
Laminate layers of fiberglass on molds to form boat decks and hulls, bodies for golf carts, automobiles, or other products.

A Timing Device Assembler and Adjuster is an individual who specializes in precision assembling or adjusting of timing devices, such as digital clocks or electronically-powered timepieces, excluding watches which are handled by a different occupation.

Perform precision assembling or adjusting, within narrow tolerances, of timing devices such as digital clocks or timing devices with electrical or electronic components. Watchmakers are included in Watch and Clock Repairers (49-9064).

The SOC 51-2090 occupational category encompasses assemblers and fabricators who work as part of a team to assemble products or components, including those with rotating tasks within the assembly process and other miscellaneous roles not separately classified.

Work as part of a team having responsibility for assembling an entire product or component of a product. Team assemblers can perform all tasks conducted by the team in the assembly process and rotate through all or most of them, rather than being assigned to a specific task on a permanent basis. May participate in making management decisions affecting the work. Includes team leaders who work as part of the team. Assemblers who continuously perform the same task are classified elsewhere in 51-2000.
All assemblers and fabricators not listed separately.

The SOC code 51-3000 refers to Food Processing Workers who are involved in various tasks within the food processing industry, including baking, meat cutting and packaging, operating roasting, baking, or drying equipment, and other miscellaneous roles related to food production.
Bakers are professionals who specialize in mixing and baking various ingredients to create a wide range of baked goods such as breads, pastries, cookies, cakes, pies, and other related items.
Mix and bake ingredients to produce breads, rolls, cookies, cakes, pies, pastries, or other baked goods. Pastry chefs in restaurants and hotels are included with Chefs and Head Cooks (35-1011).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Butchers and Other Meat, Poultry, and Fish Processing Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group refers to workers involved in specialized and non-routine tasks related to processing large portions of meat, poultry, and fish, often requiring precision skills such as slaughtering, cutting standard or premium cuts, making sausage, and packaging for sale.
Cut, trim, or prepare consumer-sized portions of meat for use or sale in retail establishments.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Meat, Poultry, and Fish Cutters and Trimmers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Use hands or hand tools to perform routine cutting and trimming of meat, poultry, and seafood.

Perform nonroutine or precision functions involving the preparation of large portions of meat. Work may include specialized slaughtering tasks, cutting standard or premium cuts of meat for marketing, making sausage, or wrapping meats. Work typically occurs in slaughtering, meat packing, or wholesale establishments. Excludes Meat, Poultry, and Fish Cutters and Trimmers (51-3022) who perform routine meat cutting.

The SOC 51-3090 Miscellaneous Food Processing Workers is an occupational category encompassing various roles involved in food processing, including operating and tending to roasting, baking, and drying machines; setting up and mixing ingredients for food production; cooking food products using specific equipment; and other unlisted food processing tasks.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend food or tobacco roasting, baking, or drying equipment, including hearth ovens, kiln driers, roasters, char kilns, and vacuum drying equipment.
Set up and operate equipment that mixes or blends ingredients used in the manufacturing of food products. Includes candy makers and cheese makers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Food Cooking Machine Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend cooking equipment, such as steam cooking vats, deep fry cookers, pressure cookers, kettles, and boilers, to prepare food products. Excludes Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders (51-3091).
All food processing workers not listed separately

The occupational category "Multiple Machine Tool Setters, OperaTors, and Tenders, Metal and PlaStic" refers to professionals who specialize in setting up, operating, or maintaining various types of cutting and forming machines made of metal or plactic materials.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group includes professionals who set up, operate, or tend various machines in metal and plastic forming processes, such as extruding thermoplastic materials into tubes or bars, forging metal parts into specific shapes, or rolling steel to form beams or plate.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Extruding and Drawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines to extrude or draw thermoplastic or metal materials into tubes, rods, hoses, wire, bars, or structural shapes.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Forging Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend forging machines to taper, shape, or form metal or plastic parts.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Rolling Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines to roll steel or plastic forming bends, beads, knurls, rolls, or plate, or to flatten, temper, or reduce gauge of material.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Machine Tool Cutting Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group includes professionals who specialize in setting up and operating various types of machinery to cut, shape, or modify metal and plastic materials into specific forms or sizes.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Cutting, Punching, and Press Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines to saw, cut, shear, slit, punch, crimp, notch, bend, or straighten metal or plastic material.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Drilling and Boring Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend drilling machines to drill, bore, ream, mill, or countersink metal or plastic work pieces.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Grinding, Lapping, Polishing, and Buffing Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend grinding and related tools that remove excess material or burrs from surfaces, sharpen edges or corners, or buff, hone, or polish metal or plastic work pieces.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Lathe and Turning Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend lathe and turning machines to turn, bore, thread, form, or face metal or plastic materials, such as wire, rod, or bar stock.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Milling and Planing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend milling or planing machines to mill, plane, shape, groove, or profile metal or plastic work pieces.

Machiniest: A skilled professional who sets up, operates, and maintains various machine tools to produce precision parts and instruments from metal materials, excluding those primarily focused on programming or operating computer numerical control (CNC) equipment.

Set up and operate a variety of machine tools to produce precision parts and instruments out of metal. Includes precision instrument makers who fabricate, modify, or repair mechanical instruments. May also fabricate and modify parts to make or repair machine tools or maintain industrial machines, applying knowledge of mechanics, mathematics, metal properties, layout, and machining procedures. Machinists who primarily program or operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment are classified in Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers (51-9160).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Metal Furnace Operators, Tenders, Pourers, and Casters
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 51-4050 occupation involves professionals who either operate and maintain furnaces to melt and refine metals for casting or pour molten metal into molds to create specific shapes and forms.

Operate or tend furnaces, such as gas, oil, coal, electric-arc or electric induction, open-hearth, or oxygen furnaces, to melt and refine metal before casting or to produce specified types of steel. Excludes Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic (51-4191).
Operate hand-controlled mechanisms to pour and regulate the flow of molten metal into molds to produce castings or ingots.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Model Makers and Patternmakers, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Model Makeers and Patternmakers in Metal and Plastic are professionals who specialize in creating working models or patterns of metal and plastic objects using various tools and techniques.
Set up and operate machines, such as lathes, milling and engraving machines, and jig borers to make working models of metal or plastic objects. Includes template makers.
Lay out, machine, fit, and assemble castings and parts to metal or plastic foundry patterns, core boxes, or match plates.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Molders and Molding Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Molders and Molding Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic are workers who specialize in setting up, operating, or tending to machines that mold, cast, or create cores for metal and plastic products, excluding those who work exclusively with non-metal materials.

Make or form wax or sand cores or molds used in the production of metal castings in foundries. Excludes Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic (51-4072) and Molders, Shapers, and Casters, Except Metal and Plastic (51-9195).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend metal or plastic molding, casting, or coremaking machines to mold or cast metal or thermoplastic parts or products.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group refers to professionals who set up, operate, and maintain various types of machinery, including cutting and forming machines made of metal or plastic.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend more than one type of cutting or forming machine tool or robot.
Tool and Die Makers are skilled workers who specialize in designing, creating, repairing, and maintaining precision metal tools, dies, and fixtures using various machine tools and techniques.
Analyze specifications, lay out metal stock, set up and operate machine tools, and fit and assemble parts to make and repair dies, cutting tools, jigs, fixtures, gauges, and machinists’ hand tools.

This SOC group comprises professionals who specialize in joining metal components using various techniques such as welding, soldering, or brazing, either manually with handheld equipment or through machine operation.
Use hand-welding, flame-cutting, hand-soldering, or brazing equipment to weld or join metal components or to fill holes, indentations, or seams of fabricated metal products.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Welding, Soldering, and Brazing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend welding, soldering, or brazing machines or robots that weld, braze, solder, or heat treat metal products, components, or assemblies. Includes workers who operate laser cutters or laser-beam machines.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Metal Workers and Plastic Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC group 51-4190 encompasses various miscellaneous metal and plastic workers who engage in tasks such as heat treating, layout work, platings, grinding, sharpening, and other related activities on metals or plastics.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend heating equipment, such as heat-treating furnaces, flame-hardening machines, induction machines, soaking pits, or vacuum equipment to temper, harden, anneal, or heat treat metal or plastic objects.

Lay out reference points and dimensions on metal or plastic stock or workpieces, such as sheets, plates, tubes, structural shapes, castings, or machine parts, for further processing. Includes shipfitters.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Plating Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend plating machines to coat metal or plastic products with chromium, zinc, copper, cadmium, nickel, or other metal to protect or decorate surfaces. Typically, the product being coated is immersed in molten metal or an electrolytic solution. Excludes Coating, Painting, and Spraying Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders (51-9124).
Perform precision smoothing, sharpening, polishing, or grinding of metal objects.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Metal Workers and Plastic Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All metal workers and plastic workers not listed separately.

Printing Workers is an occupational category encompassing various roles in printing production, including prepress technicians who format and proof text and images for printing, press operators who set up and operate different types of printing machines, and binding workers who hand or machine finish printed products.

The SOC group Broad 51-5110 Printing Workers encompasses professionals involved in various aspects of printing production, including prepress technicians who format and proof text and images for printing, press operators who set up and operate different types of printing machines, and binding workers who hand or machine finish printed products.
Format and proof text and images submitted by designers and clients into finished pages that can be printed. Includes digital and photo typesetting. May produce printing plates.
Set up and operate digital, letterpress, lithographic, flexographic, gravure, or other printing machines. Includes short-run offset printing presses.
Bind books and other publications or finish printed products by hand or machine. May set up binding and finishing machines.

SOC Group 51-6000 encompasses a wide range of professionals involved in textile production and related fields, including operating washing machines, pressers, sewing machine operators, shoe repairers, tailors, dressmakers, tanners, and other workers engaged in the creation, maintenance, or alteration of various fabric-based products.

Laundry and Dry-Cleaing Workers are professionals who operate washing or dry-cleaning machines to clean various industrial or household items, such as garments, suede, leather, fur, blankets, draperies, linens, rugs, and carpets, including spotters and dyers.

Operate or tend washing or dry-cleaning machines to wash or dry-clean industrial or household articles, such as cloth garments, suede, leather, furs, blankets, draperies, linens, rugs, and carpets. Includes spotters and dyers of these articles.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group encompasses workers who manually or mechanically press and shape various materials, such as textiles and garments, to achieve desired forms and structures.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Press or shape articles by hand or machine.

A Sewing Machine Operator is a professional who operates sewing machines to perform various tasks such as joining, reinforcing, decorating, or conducting related operations in the manufacturing process of both garment and non-garment products.
Operate or tend sewing machines to join, reinforce, decorate, or perform related sewing operations in the manufacture of garment or nongarment products.
Shoe and Leather Workers are skilled professionals who specialize in constructing, repairing, or maintaining leather products, such as shoes, luggage, and saddles, using various tools and machinery.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Shoe and Leather Workers and Repairers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Construct, decorate, or repair leather and leather-like products, such as luggage, shoes, and saddles. May use hand tools.
Operate or tend a variety of machines to join, decorate, reinforce, or finish shoes and shoe parts.
The SOC group 51-6050 encompasses skilled professionals who specialize in creating and altering garments, ranging from hand sewers to tailors, dressmakers, and custom sewers.
Sew, join, reinforce, or finish, usually with needle and thread, a variety of manufactured items. Includes weavers and stitchers.
Design, make, alter, repair, or fit garments.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Textile Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC Group 51-6060 encompasses professionals who specialize in various aspects of textile production, including setting up and operating machines for bleaching, dyeing, cutting, knitting, weaving, and winding textiles or synthetic fibers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Textile Bleaching and Dyeing Machine Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend machines to bleach, shrink, wash, dye, or finish textiles or synthetic or glass fibers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Textile Cutting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines that cut textiles.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Textile Knitting and Weaving Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines that knit, loop, weave, or draw in textiles. Excludes Sewing Machine Operators (51-6031).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Textile Winding, Twisting, and Drawing Out Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines that wind or twist textiles; or draw out and combine sliver, such as wool, hemp, or synthetic fibers. Includes slubber machine and drawing frame operators.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Miscellaneous Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Textile, Apparent, and Furnishing Workers: A group encompassing various roles involved in the textile industry, including synthetic fiber extrusion machine operators, fabric patternmakers, upholsterers for furniture and vehicles, and other related tasks not listed separately.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Extruding and Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Synthetic and Glass Fibers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines that extrude and form continuous filaments from synthetic materials, such as liquid polymer, rayon, and fiberglass.
Draw and construct sets of precision master fabric patterns or layouts. May also mark and cut fabrics and apparel.
Make, repair, or replace upholstery for household furniture or transportation vehicles.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All textile, apparel, and furnishings workers not listed separately.

Woodworkers are skilled professionals who specialize in various tasks related to cutting, shaping, and finishing wood products, including cabinetmaking, furniture refinishing, model making, and operating woodworking machinery, excluding specific roles like sawing machine operators.

Cabinetmaker and Bench Carpenters are skilled professionals who specialize in cutting, shaping, and assembling wooden articles or components for wood products, excluding those working with machinery setup and operation.

Cut, shape, and assemble wooden articles or set up and operate a variety of woodworking machines, such as power saws, jointers, and mortisers to surface, cut, or shape lumber or to fabricate parts for wood products. Excludes Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders (51-7040).

Furniture Finishers are professionals who specialize in restoring and refurbishing damaged or used furniture to its original condition, as well as creating a specific color or finish on new high-grade pieces.
Shape, finish, and refinish damaged, worn, or used furniture or new high-grade furniture to specified color or finish.

A model maker and patternmaker in wood is a skilled professional who specializes in creating detailed wooden models or patterns used for various purposes such as product design, prototyping, and casting molds.
Construct full-size and scale wooden precision models of products. Includes wood jig builders and loft workers.
Plan, lay out, and construct wooden unit or sectional patterns used in forming sand molds for castings.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders are professionals who primarily set up, operate, or tend to various woodworking machines, excluding sawing equipment, which may include CNC-controlled machinery.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Sawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Wood
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend wood sawing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Includes lead sawyers. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers (51-9160).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Except Sawing
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend woodworking machines, such as drill presses, lathes, shapers, routers, sanders, planers, and wood nailing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers (51-9160).

The SOC group 51-7090, "Miscellaneous Woodworkers," refers to woodworking professionals who perform various tasks related to cutting, shaping, and finishing wood products, but do not fit into more specific woodworker categories.
All woodworkers not listed separately.

This SOC group encompasses professionals who operate, maintain, and manage various types of power plants and systems, including nuclear reactors, electrical distribution equipment, water treatment facilities, chemical processes, gas networks, petroleum refineries, and other industrial operations.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Power Plant Operators, Distributors, and Dispatchers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group refers to professionals who manage and operate power plants, including those who control nuclear reactors (excluding other nucluer operators), distribute electricity or steam, and oversee auxiliary equipment operations in non-nuclear power generation facilities.

Operate or control nuclear reactors. Move control rods, start and stop equipment, monitor and adjust controls, and record data in logs. Implement emergency procedures when needed. May respond to abnormalities, determine cause, and recommend corrective action.
Coordinate, regulate, or distribute electricity or steam.
Control, operate, or maintain machinery to generate electric power. Includes auxiliary equipment operators. Excludes Nuclear Power Reactor Operators (51-8011).

Stationary Engineers and Boiler Operators are professionals who operate, maintain, and repair mechanical equipment like engines, generators, turbines, and boilers to ensure the efficient functioning of utilities in various buildings and industrial processes.

Operate or maintain stationary engines, boilers, or other mechanical equipment to provide utilities for buildings or industrial processes. Operate equipment such as steam engines, generators, motors, turbines, and steam boilers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant Operator is responsible for managing and controlling the entire process of treating water or wastewater using various systems and machines to ensure safe and efficient operation.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or control an entire process or system of machines, often through the use of control boards, to transfer or treat water or wastewater.

The "Miscellaneous Plant and System Operators" group includes professionals who control or operate various types of industrial processes and systems, such as chemical plants, gas distribution networks, petroleum refineries, and other miscellaneous plant operations not specifically categorized elsewhere.
Control or operate entire chemical processes or system of machines.
Distribute or process gas for utility companies and others by controlling compressors to maintain specified pressures on main pipelines.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Petroleum Pump System Operators, Refinery Operators, and Gaugers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or control petroleum refining or processing units. May specialize in controlling manifold and pumping systems, gauging or testing oil in storage tanks, or regulating the flow of oil into pipelines.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Plant and System Operators, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All plant and system operators not listed separately.

Production Workers, All Other refers to various production workers who engage in activities such as operating and tending machinery for bonding, cleaning, shaping, or other miscellaneous tasks related to the production process, excluding specific subcategories.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Chemical Processing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The occupation "Chemical Processing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders" involves operating and tending to various chemical processing equipment, excluding those related to chemical plant operations or separating machinery.

Operate or tend equipment to control chemical changes or reactions in the processing of industrial or consumer products. Equipment used includes devulcanizers, steam-jacketed kettles, and reactor vessels. Excludes Chemical Plant and System Operators (51-8091).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Separating, Filtering, Clarifying, Precipitating, and Still Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend continuous flow or vat-type equipment; filter presses; shaker screens; centrifuges; condenser tubes; precipitating, fermenting, or evaporating tanks; scrubbing towers; or batch stills. These machines extract, sort, or separate liquids, gases, or solids from other materials to recover a refined product. Includes dairy processing equipment operators. Excludes Chemical Equipment Operators and Tenders (51-9011).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Crushing, Grinding, Polishing, Mixing, and Blending Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 51-9020 Crushing, Grinding, Polishiing, Mixing, and Blending Workers category encompasses various occupations involved in manually or machine-operated processes of crushing, grinding, polishing materials like coal, glass, grain, or stone, as well as mixing and blending substances such as chemicals, tobacco, liquids, or explosive ingredients.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Crushing, Grinding, and Polishing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines to crush, grind, or polish materials, such as coal, glass, grain, stone, food, or rubber.
Grind, sand, or polish, using hand tools or hand-held power tools, a variety of metal, wood, stone, clay, plastic, or glass objects. Includes chippers, buffers, and finishers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Mixing and Blending Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines to mix or blend materials, such as chemicals, tobacco, liquids, color pigments, or explosive ingredients. Excludes Food Batchmakers (51-3092).
Cutting and Slitting Workers are individuals who use hand tools or operate machinery to cut or trim various materials such as carpet, fabric, glass, rubber, paper, or wood.
Use hand tools or hand-held power tools to cut and trim a variety of manufactured items, such as carpet, fabric, stone, glass, or rubber.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Cutting and Slicing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines that cut or slice materials, such as glass, stone, cork, rubber, tobacco, food, paper, or insulating material. Excludes Cutting, Punching, and Press Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic (51-4031), Textile Cutting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders (51-6062), and Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders (51-7040).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Extruding, Forming, Pressing, and Compacting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Extruding, Forming, Pressing, and Compacting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders are professionals who operate various machines to shape and form products like glassware, food, rubber, brick, tile, clay, waxto, tobaacco, or cosmetics, excluding shoe machine operators and paper goods machine setters.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Extruding, Forming, Pressing, and Compacting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend machines, such as glass-forming machines, plodder machines, and tuber machines, to shape and form products such as glassware, food, rubber, soap, brick, tile, clay, wax, tobacco, or cosmetics. Excludes Shoe Machine Operators and Tenders (51-6042) and Paper Goods Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders (51-9196).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Furnace, Kiln, Oven, Drier, and Kettle Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The Furnace, Kiln, Oven, Drier, and Keettle Opera torers and Ten ders occupational group involves operating or tending to heating equipment for specialized processes such as annealing glass, drying lumber, curing rubber, de-moisturizing materials, or boiling soap.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Furnace, Kiln, Oven, Drier, and Kettle Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend heating equipment other than basic metal, plastic, or food processing equipment. Includes activities such as annealing glass, drying lumber, curing rubber, removing moisture from materials, or boiling soap.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC group 51-9060 refers to professionals who inspect, test, sort, sample, or weigh nonagricultural raw materials and finished products using precision instruments and complex equipment to ensure they meet quality standards.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Inspect, test, sort, sample, or weigh nonagricultural raw materials or processed, machined, fabricated, or assembled parts or products for defects, wear, and deviations from specifications. May use precision measuring instruments and complex test equipment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: SOC 51-9070 refers to professionals who specialize in creating, repairing, appraising, and working with precious stones and metals, including jewelers, diamond polishers, gem cutters, and other related craftsmen.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Design, fabricate, adjust, repair, or appraise jewelry, gold, silver, other precious metals, or gems. Includes diamond polishers and gem cutters, and persons who perform precision casting and modeling of molds, casting metal in molds, or setting precious and semiprecious stones for jewelry and related products.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Dental and Ophthalmic Laboratory Technicians and Medical Appliance Technicians
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Dental and Opthhalmic Laboratory Technicians are professionals who specialize in constructing, repairing, or maintaining various dental appliances, optical elements, and other precision instruments used in medical fields.
Construct and repair full or partial dentures or dental appliances. Excludes Dental Assistants (31-9091).
Construct, maintain, or repair medical supportive devices such as braces, orthotics and prosthetic devices, joints, arch supports, and other surgical and medical appliances.

Cut, grind, and polish eyeglasses, contact lenses, or other precision optical elements. Assemble and mount lenses into frames or process other optical elements. Includes precision lens polishers or grinders, centerer-edgers, and lens mounters. Excludes Opticians, Dispensing  (29-2081).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Packaging and Filling Machine Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 51-9110 Packaging and Filling Machine Operaor and Tenders are workers who operate or tend to machines involved in packing and preparing industrial or consumer products for storage or shipment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Packaging and Filling Machine Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend machines to prepare industrial or consumer products for storage or shipment. Includes cannery workers who pack food products.

Painting Workers are professionals who specialize in applying paint, coating, or decorative finishes to various objects and surfaces, excluding those related to artistic design, engraving, etching, or specific metal plating.

Paint, coat, or decorate articles, such as furniture, glass, plateware, pottery, jewelry, toys, books, or leather. Excludes Artists and Related Workers (27-1010), Designers (27-1020), Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators (51-9151), and Etchers and Engravers (51-9194).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Coating, Painting, and Spraying Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend spraying or rolling machines to coat or paint any of a wide variety of products, including glassware, cloth, ceramics, metal, plastic, paper, or wood, with lacquer, silver, copper, rubber, varnish, glaze, enamel, oil, or rust-proofing materials. Includes painters of transportation vehicles such as painters in auto body repair facilities. Excludes Plating Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic (51-4193).

SOC Group Broad 51-9140 refers to Semiconductor Processing Technicians who specialize in various tasks involved in semiconductor manufacturing, including loading materials into furnaces, sawing ingots into wafers, and using x-ray equipment for crystal alignment.

Perform any or all of the following functions in the manufacture of electronic semiconductors: load semiconductor material into furnace; saw formed ingots into segments; load individual segment into crystal growing chamber and monitor controls; locate crystal axis in ingot using x-ray equipment and saw ingots into wafers; and clean, polish, and load wafers into series of special purpose furnaces, chemical baths, and equipment used to form circuitry and change conductive properties.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators are professionals who specialize in developing and processing photographic images from various media sources, including film and digital formats, often involving precision tasks like editing negatives and prints.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Perform work involved in developing and processing photographic images from film or digital media. May perform precision tasks such as editing photographic negatives and prints.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Computer Numeriallly Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers are professionals who program and operate computer-controlled tools to process various materials, setting up and maintaining equipment as needed.

Operate computer-controlled tools, machines, or robots to machine or process parts, tools, or other work pieces made of metal, plastic, wood, stone, or other materials. May also set up and maintain equipment.
Develop programs to control machining or processing of materials by automatic machine tools, equipment, or systems. May also set up, operate, or maintain equipment.

A broad occupational category encompassing various production workers who engage in activities such as operating and tending machines for bonding, cleaning, cooling, shaping, molding, and other miscellaneous tasks related to the production process, excluding specific subcategories like adhesive bonding machine operators and packers.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Adhesive Bonding Machine Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend bonding machines that use adhesives to join items for further processing or to form a completed product. Processes include joining veneer sheets into plywood; gluing paper; or joining rubber and rubberized fabric parts, plastic, simulated leather, or other materials. Excludes Shoe Machine Operators and Tenders (51-6042).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Cleaning, Washing, and Metal Pickling Equipment Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend machines to wash or clean products, such as barrels or kegs, glass items, tin plate, food, pulp, coal, plastic, or rubber, to remove impurities.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Cooling and Freezing Equipment Operators and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or tend equipment such as cooling and freezing units, refrigerators, batch freezers, and freezing tunnels, to cool or freeze products, food, blood plasma, and chemicals.

Engrave or etch metal, wood, rubber, or other materials. Includes such workers as etcher-circuit processors, pantograph engravers, and silk screen etchers. Photoengravers are included in Prepress Technicians and Workers (51-5111).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Molders, Shapers, and Casters, Except Metal and Plastic
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Mold, shape, form, cast, or carve products such as food products, figurines, tile, pipes, and candles consisting of clay, glass, plaster, concrete, stone, or combinations of materials.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Paper Goods Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Set up, operate, or tend paper goods machines that perform a variety of functions, such as converting, sawing, corrugating, banding, wrapping, boxing, stitching, forming, or sealing paper or paperboard sheets into products.
Operate machines to build tires.

Help production workers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include supplying or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Apprentice workers are classified in the appropriate production occupations (51-0000).
All production workers not listed separately. Excludes Packers and Packagers, Hand (53-7064).
This occupational category encompasses laborers who perform various tasks related to loading and unloading materials into or from tank cars, trucks, or ships, often using specialized equipment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Supervisors of Transportation and Material Moving Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 53-1040 "Supervisors of Transportation and Material Moving Workers" refers to first-line supervisors who oversee various transportation and material moving tasks, including aircraft cargo handling, helper/laborer supervision, machine operator supervision, and other related roles in the transportation sector.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Transportation and Material Moving Workers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 53-1040 "First-Line Supervisors of Transportation and Material Movers" is an occupational category encompassing various roles that involve supervising and coordinating the activities of workers in transportation and material moving fields, including aircraft cargo handling, helper/laborer supervision, machine operator supervision, and other related first-line supervisory positions.

Supervise and coordinate the activities of ground crew in the loading, unloading, securing, and staging of aircraft cargo or baggage. May determine the quantity and orientation of cargo and compute aircraft center of gravity. May accompany aircraft as member of flight crew and monitor and handle cargo in flight, and assist and brief passengers on safety and emergency procedures. Includes loadmasters.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Helpers, Laborers, and Material Movers, Hand
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of helpers, laborers, or material movers, hand.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Material-Moving Machine and Vehicle Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of material-moving machine and vehicle operators and helpers.
Supervise and coordinate activities of passenger attendants. Includes supervisors of Flight Attendants (53-2031).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Transportation Workers, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All first-line supervisors of transportation workers not listed separately.

The SOC group 53-2000 "Air Transportation Workers" encompasses various aviation professionals involved in aircraft operation, including pilots and flight engineers who navigate fixed-wing aircraft for commercial purposes, air traffic controllers who manage and ensure safe airspace operations, and flight attendants who provide passenger services and safety during flights.

Aircraft Pilots and Flight Engineers are professionals who pilot or navigate fixed-wing aircraft on scheduled or non-scheduled air carrier routes, as well as helicopters, for commercial purposes such as passenger transportation, cargo delivery, and tour services, excluding certain specialized technician roles.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Airline Pilots, Copilots, and Flight Engineers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft, usually on scheduled air carrier routes, for the transport of passengers and cargo. Requires Federal Air Transport certificate and rating for specific aircraft type used. Includes regional, national, and international airline pilots and flight instructors of airline pilots. Excludes Electro-Mechanical and Mechatronics Technologists and Technicians (17-3024).

Pilot and navigate the flight of fixed-wing aircraft on nonscheduled air carrier routes, or helicopters. Requires Commercial Pilot certificate. Includes charter pilots with similar certification, and air ambulance and air tour pilots. Excludes regional, national, and international airline pilots. Excludes Electro-Mechanical and Mechatronics Technologists and Technicians (17-3024).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Air Traffic Controllers and Airfield Operations Specialists
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 53-2020 occupation involves professionals who manage and ensure the safe operation of aircraft during takeoff, landing, and flight by controlling air traffic, coordinating with various personnel, and implementing safety procedures in accordance with established regulations.

Control air traffic on and within vicinity of airport, and movement of air traffic between altitude sectors and control centers, according to established procedures and policies. Authorize, regulate, and control commercial airline flights according to government or company regulations to expedite and ensure flight safety.

Ensure the safe takeoff and landing of commercial and military aircraft. Duties include coordination between air-traffic control and maintenance personnel, dispatching, using airfield landing and navigational aids, implementing airfield safety procedures, monitoring and maintaining flight records, and applying knowledge of weather information.

A flight attendant is an aviation professional responsible for ensuring passenger safety, comfort, and well-being during flights by monitoring cabin conditions, providing customer service, and responding to emergencies.
Monitor safety of the aircraft cabin. Provide services to airline passengers, explain safety information, serve food and beverages, and respond to emergency incidents.

The SOC Group 53-3011, "Motor Vehiule Operators," encompasses professionals who operate motor vehicles for various purposes, including ambulaance drivers and attendants providing non-emergency medical care during transportation, shuttle and taxi drivers transporting passengers on planned or unplanned routes, school bus drivers ensuring student safety, and other miscellaneous operators not falling under specific vehicle operator categories.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Ambulation drivers and attendants (SOC Code 53-101) are healthcare professionals who drive or assist in driving ambulances to transport patients from one location to another, providing non-emergency medical care during transit.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Drive ambulance or assist ambulance driver in transporting sick, injured, or convalescent persons. Assist in lifting patients.

The SOC Group 53-3030 encompasses Driver/Sales Workers and Truck Driver occupations, which involve driving trucks or tractor-trailers to deliver goods, pick up orders, and may include unloading tasks, excluding refuse collectors and light truck drivers.

Drive truck or other vehicle over established routes or within an established territory and sell or deliver goods, such as food products, including restaurant take-out items, or pick up or deliver items such as commercial laundry. May also take orders, collect payment, or stock merchandise at point of delivery. Excludes Coin, Vending, and Amusement Machine Servicers and Repairers (49-9091) and Light Truck Drivers (53-3033).

Drive a tractor-trailer combination or a truck with a capacity of at least 26,001 pounds Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW). May be required to unload truck. Requires commercial drivers’ license. Includes tow truck drivers. Excludes Refuse and Recyclable Material Collectors (53-7081).

Drive a light vehicle, such as a truck or van, with a capacity of less than 26,001 pounds Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW), primarily to pick up merchandise or packages from a distribution center and deliver. May load and unload vehicle. Excludes Couriers and Messengers (43-5021) and Driver/Sales Workers (53-3031).

The "Passenger Vehicle Drivers" SOC group includes professionals who operate various types of vehicles to transport passengers on planned or unplanned routes, adhering to safety regulations and collecting fares when applicable.
Drive a school bus to transport students. Ensure adherence to safety rules. May assist students in boarding or exiting.
Drive bus or motor coach, including regular route operations, charters, and private carriage. May assist passengers with baggage. May collect fares or tickets.

Drive a motor vehicle to transport passengers on a planned or scheduled basis. May collect a fare. Includes nonemergency medical transporters and hearse drivers. Excludes Ambulance Drivers and Attendants, Except Emergency Medical Technicians (53-3011) and Taxi Drivers (53-3054).
Drive a motor vehicle to transport passengers on an unplanned basis and charge a fare, usually based on a meter. Excludes Shuttle Drivers and Chauffeurs (53-3053).

SOC Group 53-3090 refers to "Miscellaneous Motor Vehicle Operators," which encompasses all individuals who operate motor vehicles for various purposes but do not fall under specific vehicle operator categories.
All motor vehicle operators not listed separately.

Rail Transportation Workers is an occupational group in the United States Standard Occupational Classification (SOC) system that encompasses various professionals involved in rail transportation operations, including locomotive engineers and operators, signalmen and firemen, conductors and yardmasters, subway and streetcar operators, and other miscellaneous roles not covered by specific job titles.

Locomoitive Engineers and Operators are professionals who operate various types of locomotives, excluding certain engineers, to transport passengers or freight over rail lines or within specific locations like yards.

Drive electric, diesel-electric, steam, or gas-turbine-electric locomotives to transport passengers or freight. Interpret train orders, electronic or manual signals, and railroad rules and regulations. Excludes Engineers (17-2011 through 17-2199).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Rail Yard Engineers, Dinkey Operators, and Hostlers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Drive switching or other locomotive or dinkey engines within railroad yard, industrial plant, quarry, construction project, or similar location.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Railroad Brake, Signal, and Switch Operators and Locomotive Firers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Railroad Brake, Signal, and Switch Operators are responsible for operating, monitoring, and maintaining railroad track switches, signals, and related equipment to ensure safe and efficient train operations.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Railroad Brake, Signal, and Switch Operators and Locomotive Firers
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate or monitor railroad track switches or locomotive instruments. May couple or uncouple rolling stock to make up or break up trains. Watch for and relay traffic signals. May inspect couplings, air hoses, journal boxes, and hand brakes. May watch for dragging equipment or obstacles on rights-of-way.

SOC Group 53-4030 Railroad Condutors and YaRdmasters are professionals who manage and coordinate railroad operations, including train schedules, crew activities, and switchyard movements in various settings such as industrial plants or passenger/freight trains.

Coordinate activities of switch-engine crew within railroad yard, industrial plant, or similar location. Conductors coordinate activities of train crew on passenger or freight trains. Yardmasters review train schedules and switching orders and coordinate activities of workers engaged in railroad traffic operations, such as the makeup or breakup of trains and yard switching.
Subway and Streetcar Operators are professionals who manage and operate electric suburban trains or streetcars without separate locomotives, handling passenger transportation and fare collection.
Operate subway or elevated suburban trains with no separate locomotive, or electric-powered streetcar, to transport passengers. May handle fares.

The SOC Group 53-4090 "Miscellaneous Rail Transportation Workers" refers to all individuals employed in various roles within the rail transportation sector, excluding those with specific job titles or functions.
All rail transportation workers not listed separately.

The SOC 53-5000 Water Transportation Workers occupational category encompasses professionals involved in water transportation operations, including sailors and marine oilers responsible for vessel navigation and maintenance, as well as ship captains, mates, pilots, engineers, and other related roles aboard various water vessels.

Sailors and Marine Oilers are responsible for navigating and maintaining water vessels, including tasks such as monitoring obstacles, handling cargo equipment, performing maintenance duties, and adhering to specific certification requirements.

Stand watch to look for obstructions in path of vessel, measure water depth, turn wheel on bridge, or use emergency equipment as directed by captain, mate, or pilot. Break out, rig, overhaul, and store cargo-handling gear, stationary rigging, and running gear. Perform a variety of maintenance tasks to preserve the painted surface of the ship and to maintain line and ship equipment. Must hold government-issued certification and tankerman certification when working aboard liquid-carrying vessels. Includes able seamen and ordinary seamen.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Ship and Boat Captains and Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: The SOC 53-5020 occupational group includes professionals who are responsible for commanding or supervising operations on various water vessels, such as ships and boats, requiring a U.S. Coast Guard license, excluding motorboat operators (SOC 53-5022).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Captains, Mates, and Pilots of Water Vessels
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Command or supervise operations of ships and water vessels, such as tugboats and ferryboats. Required to hold license issued by U.S. Coast Guard. Excludes Motorboat Operators (53-5022).
Operate small motor-driven boats. May assist in navigational activities.

Ship Engineers are responsible for overseeing and coordinating the operations and maintenance of engines, boilers, deck machinery, electrical systems, sanitation facilities, and refrigeration equipment on board ships, excluding engineers involved in locomotive or automotive engineering.

Supervise and coordinate activities of crew engaged in operating and maintaining engines, boilers, deck machinery, and electrical, sanitary, and refrigeration equipment aboard ship. Excludes Engineers (17-2000).

The SOC Group 53-6090, "Other Transportation Workers," encompasses a diverse range of transportation professionals who perform various duties related to ensuring safe and efficient transportation, including bridge and lock tenders, parking attendants, automobile and watercraft service attendants, aircraft servicemen, traffic technicians, and transportation inspectors.

SOC Group 53-6010 Bridge and Lock Teners are professionals responsible for operating and maintaining bridges, locks, and lighthouses to ensure safe marine passage along inland waterways, coastlines, and hazardous points of navigation.

Operate and tend bridges, canal locks, and lighthouses to permit marine passage on inland waterways, near shores, and at danger points in waterway passages. May supervise such operations. Includes drawbridge operators, lock operators, and slip bridge operators.
A Parking Attendant is an individual responsible for managing vehicle parking in various settings, such as issuing tickets, guiding customers to available spaces, and collecting fees.
Park vehicles or issue tickets for customers in a parking lot or garage. May park or tend vehicles in environments such as a car dealership or rental car facility. May collect fee.

The SOC Group Broad 53-6030 Transportation Service Attendant is an occupational category encompassing workers who provide various services to automobiles, aircraft, and other vehicles, including maintenance tasks like fueling, lubricating, cleaning, and repairing.

Service automobiles, buses, trucks, boats, and other automotive or marine vehicles with fuel, lubricants, and accessories. Collect payment for services and supplies. May lubricate vehicle, change motor oil, refill antifreeze, or replace lights or other accessories, such as windshield wiper blades or fan belts. May repair or replace tires. Excludes Cashiers (41-2011).
Service aircraft with fuel. May de-ice aircraft, refill water and cooling agents, empty sewage tanks, service air and oxygen systems, or clean and polish exterior.

A Traffic Technician is a professional who conducts field studies to assess and analyze various aspects of traffic conditions, such as volume, speed, signal effectiveness, lighting adequacy, and other related factors, under the guidance of a traffic engineer.
Conduct field studies to determine traffic volume, speed, effectiveness of signals, adequacy of lighting, and other factors influencing traffic conditions, under direction of traffic engineer.

A "Transportation Inspector" is an individual responsible for examining and ensuring the safety and compliance of transportation equipment and cargo in various modes of transportation, excluding Transportation Security Screeners.

Inspect equipment or goods in connection with the safe transport of cargo or people. Includes rail transportation inspectors, such as freight inspectors, rail inspectors, and other inspectors of transportation vehicles not elsewhere classified. Excludes Transportation Security Screeners (33-9093).
Passenger Attendants are professionals who ensure passenger safety and comfort in various modes of transportation, excluding flight attendants and bagage porters/bellhoppers.

Provide services to ensure the safety of passengers aboard ships, buses, trains, or within the station or terminal. Perform duties such as explaining the use of safety equipment, serving meals or beverages, or answering questions related to travel. Excludes Baggage Porters and Bellhops (39-6011) and Flight Attendants (53-2031).
The SOC group 53-6090, "Miscellaneous Transportation Workers," refers to transportation workers who do not fit into other specific categories within the transportation sector.
All transportation workers not listed separately.

The SOC 53-7062 "Material Moving Workers" category encompasses various professionals who are involved in handling materials or goods using manual labor techniques, excluding those who operate power equipment or engage in specialized material movement tasks.

SOC Code 53-7010 Conveyor Operators and Tenders are responsible for operating and maintaining conveyors or conveyor systems, controlling their speed and routing to move materials or products within various settings.

Control or tend conveyors or conveyor systems that move materials or products to and from stockpiles, processing stations, departments, or vehicles. May control speed and routing of materials or products.

Craane and Tower Operators are professionals who specialize in operating mechanical equipment such as cranes, towers, or booms, using their expertise to lift, move, and position materials, products, or machines with precision and safety.
Operate mechanical boom and cable or tower and cable equipment to lift and move materials, machines, or products in many directions.
A Dredge Operator is an individual responsible for operating dredging equipment to excavate and maintain navigable channels in waterways by removing materials such as sand or gravel.
Operate dredge to remove sand, gravel, or other materials in order to excavate and maintain navigable channels in waterways.
Hoist and Winch Operators are individuals who operate and maintain power-driven hoists and winches to lift and move loads in various industries, excluding those working on cranes or towers.
Operate or tend hoists or winches to lift and pull loads using power-operated cable equipment. Excludes Crane and Tower Operators (53-7021).

SOC 53-7050 Industrial Truck and Tractor Operators are professionals who operate industrial trucks or tractors to transport materials in various settings such as warehouses, construction sites, or factories, excluding logging equipment operators.
Operate industrial trucks or tractors equipped to move materials around a warehouse, storage yard, factory, construction site, or similar location. Excludes Logging Equipment Operators (45-4022).
The SOC group 53-7062 encompasses laborers who manually move materials and perform general labor tasks, excluding those using power equipment or involved in cleaning vehicles.

Wash or otherwise clean vehicles, machinery, and other equipment. Use such materials as water, cleaning agents, brushes, cloths, and hoses. Excludes Janitors and Cleaners, Except Maids and Housekeeping Cleaners (37-2011).

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Laborers and Freight, Stock, and Material Movers, Hand
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Manually move freight, stock, luggage, or other materials, or perform other general labor. Includes all manual laborers not elsewhere classified. Excludes Construction Laborers (47-2061) and Helpers, Construction Trades (47-3011 through 47-3019). Excludes Material Moving Workers (53-7011 through 53-7199) who use power equipment.
Feed materials into or remove materials from machines or equipment that is automatic or tended by other workers.
Pack or package by hand a wide variety of products and materials.

Receive, store, and issue merchandise, materials, equipment, and other items from stockroom, warehouse, or storage yard to fill shelves, racks, tables, or customers’ orders. May operate power equipment to fill orders. May mark prices on merchandise and set up sales displays. Excludes Shipping, Receiving, and Inventory Clerks (43-5071), Laborers and Freight, Stock, and Material Movers, Hand (53-7062), and Packers and Packagers, Hand (53-7064).

A "Pumping Station Operator" is an individual responsible for operating and maintaining various types of pumps, such as steam-, gas-, electric motor-, or internal combustion engine-driven compressors, to transmit, compress, recover, or control the flow of gases, liquids, slurries, or powdered materials in different industrial processes.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Gas Compressor and Gas Pumping Station Operators
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Operate steam-, gas-, electric motor-, or internal combustion-engine driven compressors. Transmit, compress, or recover gases, such as butane, nitrogen, hydrogen, and natural gas.

Tend, control, or operate power-driven, stationary, or portable pumps and manifold systems to transfer gases, oil, other liquids, slurries, or powdered materials to and from various vessels and processes.
Operate power pumps and auxiliary equipment to produce flow of oil or gas from wells in oil field.
Refuse and Recyclibale Material Collectors are workers who collect refuse or recyclable materials from containers and transport them using trucks.
Collect and dump refuse or recyclable materials from containers into truck. May drive truck.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Tank Car, Truck, and Ship Loaders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: A Tank Car, Truck, and Ship Loader is an individual responsible for loading and unloading various bulk materials into or from tank cars, trucks, or ships, while also performing related tasks such as gauging, sampling, and testing shipments.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Tank Car, Truck, and Ship Loaders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Load and unload chemicals and bulk solids, such as coal, sand, and grain, into or from tank cars, trucks, or ships, using material moving equipment. May perform a variety of other tasks relating to shipment of products. May gauge or sample shipping tanks and test them for leaks.

The SOC Group Broad 53-7190 refers to "Miscellaneous Material Moving Workers," which includes all workers involved in moving materials or goods not specifically categorized under other material moving occupations.
All material moving workers not listed separately.
This occupational category refers to various roles within the military that involve operating and maintaining aircraft, vehicles, weapons, and communication systems essential for combat operations.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Military Officer Special and Tactical Operations Leaders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition:
SOC Group: Minor
A diverse group of high-ranking military officers responsible for directing and coordinating various tactical operations, including air crew duties, aircraft landing officer tasks, and special forces leadership roles, across different combat scenarios.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Military Officer Special and Tactical Operations Leaders
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Military Officer Special and TaTical Operation Leaders encompass a diverse range of roles within the military, including air crew officers, aircraft landing officer specialists, infantry leaders, armored vehicle commanders, artillery and missile officers, and special forces officers, all responsible for directing, coordinating, and executing various tactical operations in combat and non-combat situations.

Perform and direct in-flight duties to ensure the successful completion of combat, reconnaissance, transport, and search and rescue missions. Duties include operating aircraft communications and radar equipment, such as establishing satellite linkages and jamming enemy communications capabilities; operating aircraft weapons and defensive systems; conducting preflight, in-flight, and postflight inspections of onboard equipment; and directing cargo and personnel drops.

Plan and direct the operation and maintenance of catapults, arresting gear, and associated mechanical, hydraulic, and control systems involved primarily in aircraft carrier takeoff and landing operations. Duties include supervision of readiness and safety of arresting gear, launching equipment, barricades, and visual landing aid systems; planning and coordinating the design, development, and testing of launch and recovery systems; preparing specifications for catapult and arresting gear installations; evaluating design proposals; determining handling equipment needed for new aircraft; preparing technical data and instructions for operation of landing aids; and training personnel in carrier takeoff and landing procedures.

Direct the operation of tanks, light armor, and amphibious assault vehicle units during combat situations on land or in aquatic environments. Duties include directing crew members in the operation of targeting and firing systems; coordinating the operation of advanced onboard communications and navigation equipment; directing the transport of personnel and equipment during combat; formulating and implementing battle plans, including the tactical employment of armored vehicle units; and coordinating with infantry, artillery, and air support units.

Manage personnel and weapons operations to destroy enemy positions, aircraft, and vessels. Duties include planning, targeting, and coordinating the tactical deployment of field artillery and air defense artillery missile systems units; directing the establishment and operation of fire control communications systems; targeting and launching intercontinental ballistic missiles; directing the storage and handling of nuclear munitions and components; overseeing security of weapons storage and launch facilities; and managing maintenance of weapons systems.

Manage the operation of communications, detection, and weapons systems essential for controlling air, ground, and naval operations. Duties include managing critical communication links between air, naval, and ground forces; formulating and implementing emergency plans for natural and wartime disasters; coordinating emergency response teams and agencies; evaluating command center information and need for high-level military and government reporting; managing the operation of surveillance and detection systems; providing technical information and advice on capabilities and operational readiness; and directing operation of weapons targeting, firing, and launch computer systems.

Direct, train, and lead infantry units in ground combat operations. Duties include directing deployment of infantry weapons, vehicles, and equipment; directing location, construction, and camouflage of infantry positions and equipment; managing field communications operations; coordinating with armor, artillery, and air support units; performing strategic and tactical planning, including battle plan development; and leading basic reconnaissance operations.

Lead elite teams that implement unconventional operations by air, land, or sea during combat or peacetime. These activities include offensive raids, demolitions, reconnaissance, search and rescue, and counterterrorism. In addition to their combat training, special forces officers often have specialized training in swimming, diving, parachuting, survival, emergency medicine, and foreign languages. Duties include directing advanced reconnaissance operations and evaluating intelligence information; recruiting, training, and equipping friendly forces; leading raids and invasions on enemy territories; training personnel to implement individual missions and contingency plans; performing strategic and tactical planning for politically sensitive missions; and operating sophisticated communications equipment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Military Officer Special and Tactical Operations Leaders, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All military officer special and tactical operations leaders not listed separately.

A First-Line Enlisted Military Supervisor is a military role responsible for overseeing and coordinating the activities of various first-line personnel, such as air crew members, weapons specialists, or other tactical operations specialists, while potentially performing similar tasks themselves.

First-Line Enlisted Military Supervisor is an occupational category encompassing various first-line supervisory roles within the military, responsible for overseeing and coordinating the activities of air crew members, weapons specialists/crew members, or other tactical operation specialists, while potentially performing similar tasks as those they supervise.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Air Crew Members
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Supervise and coordinate the activities of air crew members. Supervisors may also perform the same activities as the workers they supervise.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of Weapons Specialists/Crew Members
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Supervise and coordinate the activities of weapons specialists/crew members. Supervisors may also perform the same activities as the workers they supervise.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: First-Line Supervisors of All Other Tactical Operations Specialists
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Supervise and coordinate the activities of all other tactical operations specialists not classified separately above. Supervisors may also perform the same activities as the workers they supervise.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Military Enlisted Tactical Operations and Air/Weapons Specialists and Crew Members
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: Military Enlisted Taiccal Operationa and Air/Weapons Specialist are military personnel who perform critical roles in unconventionail operations, including operating and maintaining aircraft, armored vehicles, artillery, missiles, and participating in ground combat, command and control centers, or other tactical military activities.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Military Enlisted Tactical Operations and Air/Weapons Specialists and Crew Members
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: This SOC group includes military personnel who perform various critical roles in unconventionial operations, such as operating and maintaining aircraft, air defense systems, armored vehicles, artillery weapons, and specialized equipment; conducting reconnaissance and combat missions on land, sea, or air; and participating in infantry ground combat, command and control center operations, and other military tactical operations.

Perform in-flight duties to ensure the successful completion of combat, reconnaissance, transport, and search and rescue missions. Duties include operating aircraft communications and detection equipment, including establishing satellite linkages and jamming enemy communications capabilities; conducting preflight, in-flight, and postflight inspections of onboard equipment; operating and maintaining aircraft weapons and defensive systems; operating and maintaining aircraft in-flight refueling systems; executing aircraft safety and emergency procedures; computing and verifying passenger, cargo, fuel, and emergency and special equipment weight and balance data; and conducting cargo and personnel drops.

Operate and maintain catapults, arresting gear, and associated mechanical, hydraulic, and control systems involved primarily in aircraft carrier takeoff and landing operations. Duties include installing and maintaining visual landing aids; testing and maintaining launch and recovery equipment using electric and mechanical test equipment and hand tools; activating airfield arresting systems, such as crash barriers and cables, during emergency landing situations; directing aircraft launch and recovery operations using hand or light signals; and maintaining logs of airplane launches, recoveries, and equipment maintenance.

Operate tanks, light armor, and amphibious assault vehicles during combat situations on land or in aquatic environments. Duties include driving armored vehicles that require specialized training; operating and maintaining targeting and firing systems; operating and maintaining advanced onboard communications and navigation equipment; transporting personnel and equipment in a combat environment; and operating and maintaining auxiliary weapons, including machine guns and grenade launchers.

Target, fire, and maintain weapons used to destroy enemy positions, aircraft, and vessels. Field artillery crew members predominantly use guns, cannons, and howitzers in ground combat operations, while air defense artillery crew members predominantly use missiles and rockets. Naval artillery crew members predominantly use torpedoes and missiles launched from a ship or submarine. Duties include testing, inspecting, and storing ammunition, missiles, and torpedoes; conducting preventive and routine maintenance on weapons and related equipment; establishing and maintaining radio and wire communications; and operating weapons targeting, firing, and launch computer systems.

Operate and monitor communications, detection, and weapons systems essential for controlling air, ground, and naval operations. Duties include maintaining and relaying critical communications between air, naval, and ground forces; implementing emergency plans for natural and wartime disasters; relaying command center information to high-level military and government decisionmakers; monitoring surveillance and detection systems, such as air defense; interpreting and evaluating tactical situations and making recommendations to superiors; and operating weapons targeting, firing, and launch computer systems.

Operate weapons and equipment in ground combat operations. Duties include operating and maintaining weapons, such as rifles, machine guns, mortars, and hand grenades; locating, constructing, and camouflaging infantry positions and equipment; evaluating terrain and recording topographical information; operating and maintaining field communications equipment; assessing need for and directing supporting fire; placing explosives and performing minesweeping activities on land; and participating in basic reconnaissance operations.

Implement unconventional operations by air, land, or sea during combat or peacetime as members of elite teams. These activities include offensive raids, demolitions, reconnaissance, search and rescue, and counterterrorism. In addition to their combat training, special forces members often have specialized training in swimming, diving, parachuting, survival, emergency medicine, and foreign languages. Duties include conducting advanced reconnaissance operations and collecting intelligence information; recruiting, training, and equipping friendly forces; conducting raids and invasions on enemy territories; laying and detonating explosives for demolition targets; locating, identifying, defusing, and disposing of ordnance; and operating and maintaining sophisticated communications equipment.

SOCGroups.SOCTitle: Military Enlisted Tactical Operations and Air/Weapons Specialists and Crew Members, All Other
SOCGroups.SOCDefinition: All military enlisted tactical operations and air/weapons specialists and crewmembers not listed separately.
